summary: Paul Merson, a Sky Sports pundit, reignited his feud with Tottenham midfielder Andros Townsend by mocking his late substitution in a 0-0 draw against Burnley, where Townsend played only the last seven minutes. Merson had previously criticized Townsend's inclusion in the England team, suggesting it lowered the selection standards. However, Townsend proved Merson wrong by scoring a stunning equalizer for England in a 1-1 friendly draw against Italy in Turin. Merson admitted his mistake, congratulating Townsend on the goal, though he maintained his opinion was based on Townsend's earlier poor performance. Townsend responded to Merson's initial criticism on Twitter after his goal for England. Despite a seeming resolution, Merson took another jab at Townsend following the Burnley match.

Chelsea have made a formal offer to acquire 22-year-old FC Tokyo forward Yoshinori Muto, as confirmed by FC Tokyo president Naoki Ogane. Muto, a Japan international with 11 caps and 1 goal, has been with FC Tokyo since 2013, scoring 16 goals in 37 appearances. If the transfer to Chelsea is completed this summer, Muto will be loaned to Chelsea's partner club, Vitesse Arnhem, next season, and would become the first Japanese player to represent Chelsea. A potential £4million deal has been mentioned, though Muto has not yet decided on the move, despite feeling honored by the offer. His interest from Chelsea is unrelated to the club's £200million sponsorship deal with Yokohama Rubber, which will see the company become Chelsea's shirt sponsor from the 2015-16 season. Muto, who recently graduated with an economics degree from Keio University, has shown strong form, scoring 13 goals in his debut season and 3 in 4 games this season, helping FC Tokyo to third place in the J-League.

A large-scale study published in the medical journal Pediatrics found that babies given antibiotics in the first six months of life are more likely to be overweight as toddlers. The research, conducted by Finnish scientists, involved over 12,000 healthy two-year-olds and showed that one in five boys and one in ten girls were overweight or obese by age two, with a higher likelihood among those who received antibiotics early in life or repeatedly during infancy. Boys were particularly prone to weight gain and were slightly taller when exposed to antibiotics. The study suggests that antibiotics might contribute to weight gain by altering gut bacteria, which could affect food absorption and appetite, potentially playing a role in the global childhood obesity epidemic. Lead author Dr. Antti Saari emphasized the need for cautious use of antibiotics due to these potential effects. Additionally, concerns about over-prescription of antibiotics include increased risks of other health issues like eczema and digestive problems, as well as the development of antibiotic-resistant superbugs.

During the Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace, a Queen's Guard slipped on a manhole cover and fell in front of hundreds of tourists. The incident, which occurred last week, was captured on camera by holidaymaker David Meadwell from Newcastle-upon-Tyne. The guard lost his footing, knocked his bearskin hat, dropped his rifle, and quickly got back up, visibly embarrassed as his colleagues continued marching. The fall is believed to have been caused by the metal protectors on the soles of his boots. The Changing of the Guard is a popular daily event in summer, drawing thousands of spectators, and the guards are fully operational soldiers, not just ceremonial. The Ministry of Defence declined to comment on the incident.

The iconic miniseries "Roots," which originally aired in 1977 and attracted over 100 million viewers, is being remade by A&E networks for a 2016 release. The new version will be simulcast on A&E, Lifetime, and History, focusing on the story of Kunta Kinte, an African sold into slavery in America. LeVar Burton, who played Kinte in the original, will co-executive produce this contemporary adaptation, which draws more from Alex Haley's novel and involves consultation with history scholars for authenticity. The remake aims to introduce this powerful story to a new generation amidst a backdrop of significant racial events and milestones in the U.S., including Barack Obama's presidency and ongoing racial unrest. Executive producers, including Mark Wolper, emphasize the importance of continuing to tell Kinte's story.

A former royal footman, Christopher Lawler, has claimed that on his first day at Clarence House in January 1978, palace aides attempted to force him into an orgy. He alleges he was pinned to a chair and groped, leading him to leave the job the same day. The incident, which occurred at the Queen Mother’s London residence, left him traumatized. After initially being ignored, his complaints were eventually passed to Scotland Yard following renewed interest in historical abuse cases last year. Police are now investigating, and while a retired royal aide has been interviewed and denied involvement, the Royal Household has pledged full cooperation with the ongoing probe.

Jesse and Melissa Meek, an Oregon couple, announced their pregnancy through a rap video parody set to the theme song of the '90s sitcom 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air.' The video, filmed in their car, has garnered over 1.7 million views on YouTube. In the clip, they rap about their life in Happy Valley, Oregon, the pressure from family and friends to start a family, and their quick conception after just two months of trying. The video concludes with them sharing a sonogram of their unborn child. It took five takes to film, and they created it to inform loved ones living far away. The couple was surprised by the video's viral success and may make another video to reveal the baby's gender. Additionally, Jesse is the great-great-grandson of Oregon pioneer Joseph Lafayette Meek, and Melissa had previously recorded Jesse's reaction to the pregnancy news using a tag on their dog.

A dress worn by Vivien Leigh as Scarlett O'Hara in the 1939 film "Gone With the Wind" sold for $137,000 at a Heritage Auctions event in Beverly Hills, California. The gray jacket and skirt ensemble, originally slate blue-gray but faded over time, was featured in key scenes of the movie. This dress was part of a collection of over 150 items from the film auctioned from the private collection of James Tumblin, who started collecting memorabilia in the 1960s. Other notable items sold include a straw hat worn by Leigh for $52,500, a suit worn by Clark Gable as Rhett Butler for $55,000, and a black bonnet worn by Leigh and Olivia De Havilland for $30,000. "Gone With the Wind," marking its 75th anniversary last year, is based on Margaret Mitchell's 1936 novel and features Hattie McDaniel, the first African-American to win an Academy Award.

A two-year-old boy fell into a cheetah exhibit at the Cleveland Metroparks Zoo after being dangled over the edge by his parents. The incident occurred on a Saturday around 3pm when the child slipped from his mother's hold, falling 10 to 12 feet into the pit. The boy was quickly rescued by his parents before emergency services arrived. He sustained minor bumps, bruises, and a leg injury but was not attacked by the cheetahs, who did not approach him or his parents. The child was taken to MetroHealth Medical Center and listed in stable condition. Zoo officials, supported by eyewitness accounts, believe the child was dangled over the railing, and the zoo plans to press child endangerment charges against the family. The cheetah exhibit was closed following the incident.

In Handsworth, Birmingham, a non-functional speed camera, previously used to enforce a 30mph limit on a residential road, has been mysteriously repositioned to face directly at a house's front door. This camera is among 300 fixed speed and traffic cameras in the West Midlands that were decommissioned in March 2013 due to obsolete technology. Since then, speed enforcement in the region has relied on mobile camera units, motorway fixed cameras, and traffic officers. Birmingham City Council, aware of the camera's repositioning on Wellington Road, plans to investigate and possibly remove it, with no intention to include it in a new digital technology pilot at select sites. The house owners were unavailable for comment.

Usain Bolt, a six-time Olympic gold medallist, will compete at the IAAF/BTC World Relays in the Bahamas on May 2 and 3 as part of the Jamaican team, as announced by the Jamaica Athletics Administrative Association. Bolt expressed his enthusiasm for participating, stating he is fit, healthy, and ready to run, and highlighted the fun atmosphere of the previous year's event and Jamaica's successful relay tradition. JAAA General Secretary Garth Gayle noted their pleasure in Bolt's availability, anticipating impressive performances. The full Jamaican team list will be announced soon. Bolt emphasized his commitment to making his country proud when representing Jamaica.

Neymar and Dani Alves, teammates at Barcelona, demonstrated their support for the club by attending a basketball El Clasico match on Thursday night with Neymar's sister, Rafaella. Barcelona's basketball team secured a close 85-80 win in the Euro League game, though Real Madrid still leads the division by points difference. Additionally, Neymar recently captained Brazil to a 1-0 victory over Chile at the Emirates Stadium, enduring tough challenges during the match. Before the international break, Barcelona, under Luis Enrique, had won their football El Clasico, leading La Liga by four points. Neymar and his team are set to face Celta Vigo in their next La Liga match as they aim for a treble of trophies.

Italy is experiencing a significant influx of migrants from Africa and the Middle East attempting to reach Europe, with 8,480 migrants rescued between Friday and Monday, as reported by the Italian coast guard. On Monday alone, the coast guard responded to SOS calls from 20 distressed boats. There are concerns from Save the Children about a possible capsizing of a ship carrying 550 migrants off the Libyan coast, with 400 potentially missing, though the Italian coast guard has not confirmed this incident and found no evidence of it during their search. Over 10,000 migrants arrived in Italy in the first three months of 2015, with about 2,000 rescued in early April. Most of these migrants originate from West Africa, Somalia, and Syria, using Libya as a transit point. Tragically, at least 480 migrants have died crossing the Mediterranean this year due to bad weather, overcrowded boats, and abandonment by ship crews.

Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger is pleased that Alexis Sanchez chose to join Arsenal over Liverpool, though he is unsure of the exact reasons behind Sanchez's decision. Sanchez, who transferred from Barcelona for £32 million, has made a significant impact in English football, scoring 19 goals this season. Wenger acknowledges Liverpool's interest in Sanchez might have been linked to negotiations over Luis Suarez's move to Barcelona. He praises Sanchez's quick adaptation, highlighting his qualities, efficiency, work-rate, and fighting spirit. Ahead of a crucial Premier League match against Liverpool, Wenger downplays rumors of a potential transfer for Liverpool's Raheem Sterling and commends Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers for his team’s development despite challenges like Suarez's departure and Daniel Sturridge's injury.

Sir Bradley Wiggins, a four-time Olympic champion and 2012 Tour de France winner, will attempt to break cycling's hour record on June 7 at London's Olympic Velodrome, specifically at the Lee Valley VeloPark. The 35-year-old aims to ride the furthest distance in 60 minutes, challenging the current record of 52.491km set by Australian Rohan Dennis in February. Wiggins, who recently concluded his Team Sky career at the Paris-Roubaix race, views the Hour Record as a prestigious challenge in cycling. He hopes to inspire others and expects to set a lasting mark, performing in front of a capacity crowd of 6,000, with tickets on sale from April 19 and the event broadcast live on Sky Sports. Additionally, Wiggins is targeting a British record eighth Olympic medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics and will compete in the inaugural Tour de Yorkshire before focusing on the hour record attempt.

Serena Williams, the World No. 1 and twice French Open champion, described her challenging match against Sara Errani in the Fed Cup as an 'eye-opener' for the claycourt season. Despite winning 4-6, 7-6(3), 6-3, Williams was critical of her performance, realizing she wasn't as prepared for clay as she thought, having played as if on hard court. The US team lost 3-2 to Italy, with Williams and Alison Riske defeated in doubles by Errani and Flavia Pennetta 6-0, 6-3, resulting in the US being relegated to World Group II. Williams acknowledged the need to adapt her game for clay and hit numerous shots if necessary. US captain Mary Joe Fernandez emphasized the need for harder work and optimism about returning to the elite group next year with many top 100 players on the team.

River Plate, an Argentine football club, is interested in re-signing their former striker Radamel Falcao, who is currently on a season-long loan at Manchester United from Monaco. Falcao, who played for River Plate from 2001 to 2009 and scored 34 goals in 90 appearances, has struggled at Manchester United, scoring only four Premier League goals. Despite this, he recently equaled Colombia’s all-time goalscoring record with 24 goals by scoring three times in two international games. River Plate's vice president, Matias Patanian, expressed the club's desire to have Falcao back, stating that "the doors are open," although he acknowledges that finalizing a deal is complicated. It is uncertain whether Manchester United will opt to keep Falcao or if he will return to Monaco.

Ella Henderson, a 19-year-old X Factor finalist and pop star, has been named the official face of Batiste's 2015 'Ready For It' campaign, marking her first brand collaboration. Known for her impressive vocals and long flowing hair, Henderson is featured in campaign images against a vibrant, blurred city background, showcasing various hairstyles including wavy locks and a tousled half-ponytail. She wears stylish outfits like a black fringed leather jacket and a maxi dress with animal-print panels. The partnership with the UK's top dry shampoo brand was facilitated by the MILES agency and includes a TV advertising campaign featuring her single, "Mirror Man." Henderson expressed excitement about the collaboration, noting her regular use of the product. Mark Hargreaves, CEO of Crown Talent & Media Group, highlighted the natural synergy between Henderson and Batiste, anticipating an exciting 2015.

In Kenosha, Wisconsin, a billboard featuring Officer Pablo Torres, who fatally shot Aaron Siler on March 14, has caused outrage among Siler's family and friends. Siler, 26, was killed after arming himself during a confrontation following a vehicle and foot pursuit; he was wanted on a felony probation and parole warrant. Torres, currently on leave pending investigation, is also linked to another recent shooting of Terry Knight, which was deemed justified. The billboard, funded by the Kenosha Professional Police Association, thanks the community for support and features Torres with his dog, but has been called 'disrespectful' by Siler’s loved ones, who demand its removal. The police association insists no offense was intended, aiming only to express gratitude for community support during challenging times. The investigation into Siler's death is ongoing.

Eight Iranian border guards were killed in clashes with militants near the Pakistan border in the southeastern town of Negur, as reported by Iranian state media. Three militants were killed by Iranian forces during the conflict. The militant group Jaish al Adal, an anti-Iranian Sunni Muslim group aiming to counter Iranian influence in Pakistan, claimed responsibility for the attack. The group has a history of targeting Shiites and conducting attacks on Iranian territory, including a deadly 2013 incident where 14 Iranian border guards were killed. Iranian officials have requested Pakistani authorities to apprehend the surviving attackers, who reportedly crossed into Iran from Pakistan and often flee back to Balochistan after such attacks. Iran has criticized Pakistan for not controlling these terrorists. Pakistan condemned the attack as terrorism, is investigating the incident, and has pledged to apprehend and bring to justice any militants who entered Pakistan post-attack.

The passage discusses a unique political exchange in Japan's parliament where Defense Minister Gen Nakatani addressed a query from lawmaker Antonio Inoki about UFO encounters. Nakatani clarified that Japan's Air Self Defense Force has never encountered an extraterrestrial UFO, though they do scramble jets to investigate potential airspace violations, often finding birds or other non-aircraft objects. Antonio Inoki, a former wrestler and founder of New Japan Pro Wrestling, is a colorful figure in Japanese politics with a history of international diplomacy efforts and a personal claim of having seen a UFO, though he remains unsure about the existence of aliens. This discussion echoes a previous instance in 2007 when another Japanese Defense Minister considered the legal implications of defending against an alien invasion under Japan's pacifist constitution.

A 35-year-old passenger named Jin Pai was hospitalized with deep cuts on his leg and buttocks after breaking a toilet at Hefei Xinqiao International Airport in Hefei, the capital of Anhui Province, China. Jin was squatting on the toilet rim, concerned about cleanliness, when it collapsed and shattered, causing his injuries. Embarrassed, he initially called his traveling companions for help before being taken to a hospital in Hefei for treatment, receiving dozens of stitches. Although Jin later told police he was sitting, not standing, to possibly avoid compensation, authorities deemed the incident an accident. A police spokesman reminded the public that toilets are meant for sitting, not standing.

Kevin Rebbie, a 56-year-old from Limerick Township, Pennsylvania, was arrested for sexually abusing a 15-year-old girl over four years and recording her and others with a hidden camera in a bathroom. The abuse began when the girl was nine and continued until she was 13. The camera, discovered by the girl under a bathroom sink, had captured 41 videos over several years, including explicit content which Rebbie uploaded to his computer. He faces charges including aggravated indecent assault and invasion of privacy. Rebbie's preliminary hearing is scheduled for May 1, with bail set at $500,000.

Japanese photographer Yûki Aoyama, aged 37, has created a unique series of images featured in a book roughly translated as "Daughter and Salary Man." The photographs depict serious-looking teenage daughters standing next to their fathers, who are captured mid-air in energetic and dramatic poses. While the daughters wear casual clothing and often maintain a po-faced expression or smile at the camera, the fathers are dressed in sharp suits, embodying the "salary man" aesthetic. The images, set against various Japanese landmarks, aim to show the fathers expressing a fun, heroic side, contrasting their usual serious demeanor. Although some older fathers appear pained during their jumps, the series has garnered significant online interest for its curious and creative concept.

The passage discusses the recent dismissal of Paul Downton as England's managing director and the subsequent focus on the upcoming county championship season. Central to the narrative is Kevin Pietersen, who is contemplating a return to the England cricket team. During a Surrey team photo shoot at the KIA Oval ahead of the season start on April 19 against Glamorgan, Pietersen appeared both reflective and jovial. His potential return to the international scene is facilitated by Downton's departure, as Pietersen was controversially dropped from the team in 2014 following a disastrous Ashes tour in Australia. Now back with Surrey, Pietersen aims to reclaim his spot in the England Test set-up, especially with the Ashes series on home soil approaching this summer.

Ceahlaul Piatra Neamt, a Romanian club facing relegation, sacked their Brazilian coach Ze Maria for the second time in a week. Initially fired on Wednesday due to poor performance, Ze Maria was reinstated the next day by owner Angelo Massone, only to be dismissed again after a 2-0 loss to FC Botosani on Saturday. This defeat left Ceahlaul 16th in the league standings, six points from safety. Ze Maria, a former Brazil defender with 25 caps and a career at Inter Milan and Parma, had taken over as the club's third coach this season in January, replacing Florin Marin. He will now be succeeded by Serbian coach Vanya Radinovic.

Radamel Falcao, on a season-long loan from Monaco to Manchester United, has underperformed, scoring only four goals, and is unlikely to be signed permanently for £46 million. Despite not being happy at Monaco, his former teammate Nabil Dirar believes Falcao regrets the move to United, as he could have played more and participated in the Champions League if he had stayed. Falcao's struggles are attributed to not reaching his previous performance levels after a serious knee injury.

New Zealand police are seeking public assistance to identify a very tall man who robbed a dairy in east Christchurch on Union St. The robbery occurred around 12:30 pm on Saturday, where the suspect, wearing a distinctive cartoon mask and a fluoro orange sweatshirt, demanded cash from the dairy owner's daughter. He escaped with the till drawer containing up to $1,500. Security footage captured the incident, and although no weapons were visible, the suspect remains at large. The dairy owner's daughter was left shaken, and the family expressed fear due to the unknown identity of the masked robber. Police urge anyone with information to contact Crimestoppers at 0800 555 111 or message them online.

Kaitlyn Granado, a 24-year-old math teacher at MacArthur High School in Irving, Texas, was arrested twice for inappropriate relationships with underage students. Initially arrested on March 19 for allowing a 15-year-old student to touch her breasts and admitting to kissing him, she was released on bail but subsequently suspended and placed on administrative leave. Granado was arrested again on Monday after a second 15-year-old student accused her of having sex with him in her car on consecutive nights, January 18 and 19, near another school in Dallas. She was booked into Irving County Jail and released after posting a $50,000 bail. The school district has taken immediate action, ensuring she is not allowed to work with students or be on school property, though her plea regarding the second set of charges remains unknown.

A video capturing a large crocodile swimming through a marina in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, with a dead pet dog in its jaws has garnered over half a million views online. The incident was witnessed by New Zealander Tim Weston, who was on holiday with his wife. The dog, belonging to a local bike shop owner, was attacked after approaching the water's edge out of curiosity. The crocodile, a common sight in the area due to nearby mangroves and a sanctuary, held the dog in its mouth for hours as it moved through the marina. Social media reactions to the video, posted on the Bogged Facebook page, include horror and negative sentiments towards crocodiles. In Puerto Vallarta, a Mexican beach resort, American Crocodiles, which can grow up to 6 meters, are frequently seen due to urbanization bringing them closer to human habitats.

Steve Bruce remains confident in keeping Hull City in the Barclays Premier League despite a 2-0 loss to Southampton, which left them just two points above the relegation zone. Initially targeting 10 wins for survival, Bruce now hopes that eight or nine might suffice, as Hull has only secured six wins so far. The defeat came from a penalty by James Ward-Prowse and a late goal by Graziano Pelle, despite Hull's strong performance in the first half. With challenging upcoming matches against teams like Liverpool and Manchester United, Bruce believes his team can secure the necessary results to stay up. He attributes Hull's struggles to long-term injuries to key players like Mohamed Diame, James Chester, Michael Dawson, Nikica Jelavic, and Robert Snodgrass. Meanwhile, Southampton moved to fifth in the league table, though their manager Ronald Koeman faced internal issues regarding penalty-taking decisions during the match.

Ian Guffick, a teacher at Mitton Manor Primary School in Tewkesbury, Gloucestershire, was banned from teaching for at least two years after he allowed pupils to alter their SATs exam answers after the test session had ended and changed some answers himself. This breach of exam rules led to an investigation by the local education authority, resulting in the Department for Education annulling all SATs results for the school in 2014. Guffick admitted to the allegations, acknowledging his actions as unacceptable professional conduct, though he claimed he only asked pupils to make answers more legible. The National College for Teaching and Leadership panel found his conduct dishonest but not fraudulent, noting his regret and cooperation during the investigation. He was given 28 days to appeal the ban to the High Court.

Anders Lindegaard, a Manchester United goalkeeper, has had limited playing time at the club since joining in 2010 from Norwegian side Aalesunds, making only 19 league appearances over five seasons. Currently third-choice behind David de Gea and Victor Valdes, he has been told he can leave United, with a potential transfer to FC Midtjylland falling through due to pricing disagreements. Off the pitch, Lindegaard enjoys a happier life, having married Swedish model Misse Beqiri in a romantic beach wedding in Mauritius last year. The couple, who have been dating since 2012, have a son together. Beqiri, with Albanian roots, is active on Instagram, where she shares modeling photos and personal updates to her over 17,000 followers. Lindegaard often posts about his family life on social media, recently sharing a day off with his wife in Cheshire, Manchester.

The glowing blue letters that once adorned Yankee Stadium, owned by Hall of Famer Reggie Jackson, did not sell at a Sotheby's auction despite an expected price of $300,000 to $600,000. Jackson, who bought the 10-feet-tall letters after the stadium's final game in 2008, attended the auction and had hoped a new generation would enjoy this iconic piece of Yankees and New York City history. The letters, installed in 1976 atop the stadium near Grand Concourse in the Bronx, received no bids, even after a Sotheby's employee attempted to start bidding at $260,000. In contrast, a New York Mets bullpen car from the late 60s, estimated at $20,000 to $30,000, sold for $112,500 at the same auction.

Liverpool manager Brendan Rodgers addressed professional conduct issues with players Raheem Sterling and Jordon Ibe after incidents involving Sterling inhaling nitrous oxide and both being pictured with shisha pipes. Rodgers spoke to them in his office but decided against disciplinary action, emphasizing the importance of understanding professional responsibilities. Sterling will lead Liverpool’s attack in the upcoming FA Cup semi-final against Aston Villa at Wembley, replacing the injured Daniel Sturridge. Captain Steven Gerrard is available for the match after a three-match suspension, though Rodgers has not confirmed his immediate recall. Rodgers is focused on guiding Liverpool to their first FA Cup final under his management, reflecting on past near successes in the title race and Capital One Cup as part of the team's growth journey.

Mesut Ozil, Arsenal's playmaker, returned to London after the international break and shared a photo on Twitter relaxing at home with his dog, captioned 'Home Sweet Home'. The German midfielder performed well in Germany's 2-0 victory over Georgia in a Euro 2016 qualifier. Ozil, who joined Arsenal from Real Madrid for £42.5 million in 2013, missed Arsenal's recent match against Newcastle due to illness but is expected to play in the upcoming Premier League game against Liverpool at the Emirates Stadium. Despite rumors of being spotted in a Berlin nightclub, which were dismissed by manager Arsene Wenger, Ozil has been in good form since recovering from injury, contributing four assists and three goals since January. He also expressed that he has adapted well to the demanding schedule of English football, enjoying the frequent matches and feeling that he fits in perfectly.

Barcelona club president Josep Maria Bartomeu has expressed strong support for manager Luis Enrique, dismissing rumors of a replacement. Enrique, who began his tenure last summer with a two-year contract, has led Barcelona to a position just six games from winning the La Liga title. Bartomeu highlighted his satisfaction with Enrique's performance, noting the team's potential to win three trophies this season. Enrique's contract extends until 2016, and discussions about its future are postponed as the focus remains on current competitions, including La Liga and the Champions League. Additionally, Barcelona recently secured a victory against Valencia with goals from Luis Suarez and Lionel Messi.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, has agreed to a new long-term contract worth approximately £100,000 per week, extending until 2020. This follows contract extensions for teammates Daniel Sturridge and Philippe Coutinho. Henderson, who joined Liverpool from Sunderland in 2011 for £16 million, has shown significant improvement under manager Brendan Rodgers, contributing 13 assists and seven goals this season. At 24, he is a potential candidate to replace Steven Gerrard as club captain when Gerrard leaves for LA Galaxy. Meanwhile, contract talks with Raheem Sterling are postponed until the end of the season, though Liverpool's Chief Executive, Ian Ayre, anticipates Sterling's long-term stay at the club.

Filipe Luis, a full back at Chelsea, has expressed his desire to remain with the club until the end of his three-year contract, despite interest from his former team, Atletico Madrid, to bring him back. Having signed with Chelsea from the Spanish champions last July, Luis has found it challenging to secure the left back position. However, he remains committed to Chelsea. Additionally, after participating in Brazil’s friendly victories against France and Chile, Luis is now focusing on the Premier League title run-in. Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho emphasizes the importance of focus and winning every game, preparing the team for the challenging nine games ahead.

Nathan Hughes, a Wasps No 8, had his three-match suspension overturned on appeal after accidentally knocking out Northampton's George North with his knee during a try on March 27. Initially red-carded and banned for recklessness, the decision was reversed following significant criticism and an appeal by Wasps, clearing Hughes of any foul play as the incident was deemed accidental. George North, who suffered his third concussion in two months, was left unconscious and advised to rest for at least a month. Hughes missed Wasps’ Champions Cup quarter-final loss to Toulon but is now eligible to play, though not scheduled for the upcoming game against London Welsh. The appeal panel, led by Jeremy Summers, concluded no foul play occurred after reviewing new evidence.

A fiery, deep red sunset was observed in Washington on Sunday, captivating Seattle native Tim Durkan who shared aerial photographs of the phenomenon on CNN iReport. The unusual sunset color was caused by smoke from wildfires in southeastern Siberia, started by farmers burning grass and exacerbated by strong winds on April 14. These fires destroyed numerous villages before being extinguished by rescue crews. The smoke was carried by atmospheric winds across the Pacific Ocean to the Pacific Northwest, affecting areas in Oregon, Washington, and British Columbia. The intense red color of the sunset results from smoke particles filtering out shorter wavelength colors of sunlight, allowing reds and oranges to dominate, particularly during sunrise and sunset when light travels through more atmosphere. As the smoke clears, air quality will improve and the sunsets will return to normal.

Becky Schoenig from St. Louis, Missouri, experienced the theft of her new 2015 Ford Fusion from her driveway. The car was later recovered on April 1 following a tip from Mick Sexton, who recognized the vehicle. Upon its return, Schoenig discovered that the thieves had modified the car with red spray-painted rims, red detailing on the sides, and orange accents on the steering wheel. Embracing the unexpected changes, she humorously thanked the thieves on Facebook for "pimping out" her vehicle. Despite the lighthearted response, she faced issues like a lingering smell of cigarettes and marijuana, prompting a professional cleaning. In gratitude to Sexton, Schoenig is creating a special smoothie named "Sexton on Wheels" at her restaurant, The Hot Pot. Her friend Marlene Trice described her as vibrant, happy, and someone who loves to make people laugh.

Manchester City players risk losing £500,000 each in bonuses if they fail to qualify for the Champions League this season. The team, including stars like Sergio Aguero and Yaya Toure, operates under incentivised contracts to comply with financial fairplay rules. Currently in fourth place in the Premier League, a position that requires a qualifying round for Champions League entry, City are just four points ahead of Liverpool after a recent loss to Manchester United in the Manchester derby. The squad collectively has about £12 million in bonuses at stake. Manager Manuel Pellegrini has expressed disappointment over the team's performance, noting a significant decline since starting 2015 joint-top with Chelsea, with seven losses including early exits from the FA Cup and Champions League. Upcoming matches include games against West Ham United, Aston Villa, and Tottenham Hotspur, among others. Meanwhile, Manchester United's manager Louis van Gaal is optimistic about attracting top talent in the next transfer window following their recent victory over City.

In a 'mini-derby' match, Manchester United's Under 18s defeated Manchester City 1-0 at Moss Lane, Altrincham, with a crowd of nearly 1,000 watching for free. The match, distinct from senior games, featured 13 English players, 10 of whom were local Mancunians. Callum Gribbin scored the winning goal with a stunning free-kick just before the hour mark, showcasing his skill after earning a foul. United's coach, Paul McGuinness, aimed to simulate a senior team experience, using a formation with three defenders and wingbacks. Despite chances from both sides, including a close call from City's Marcus Wood and a missed opportunity by United's Marcus Rashford, United secured the victory. This result positions United two points behind league leaders Middlesbrough with a game in hand, while City has lost both matches in the Barclays Under 18s Premier League play-off series. The game highlighted promising homegrown talent on both teams, potentially deserving future first-team opportunities.

Joe Hart, the England and Manchester City goalkeeper, praised Italian goalkeeper Gianluigi Buffon as a 'legend of the game' after Buffon earned his 147th cap during a 1-1 draw with Italy. Hart, who celebrated his 50th cap in the same match at Juventus Stadium, expressed admiration for Buffon, highlighting the 37-year-old's influence and professionalism as an inspiration. Hart, 10 years younger than Buffon, emphasized his desire to continue learning and increasing his cap count, expressing pride in his achievements and his intent to keep performing well for both club and country.

Chipotle, a Mexican fast-casual restaurant chain, is entering the $70 billion food delivery market by partnering with the Postmates app to offer delivery services for online and mobile orders in 67 cities. This move includes a 9% service charge and delivery fees starting at $5, varying by distance and demand. Previously declining third-party delivery collaborations, Chipotle has now approved working with Postmates, which uses independent contractors similar to Uber. The chain has recently gained attention with visits from presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Marco Rubio. Additionally, other major chains like Starbucks, Taco Bell, McDonald's, and Burger King are also exploring or implementing delivery services in various markets.

The parents of Martin Richard, the youngest victim of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings, have publicly urged the Justice Department to remove the death penalty as a potential sentence for Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, who was recently convicted on all 30 charges related to the attack. In an opinion piece for The Boston Globe titled "To end the anguish, drop the death penalty," Bill and Denise Richard expressed the profound grief and trauma their family has endured, including the death of their 8-year-old son Martin and severe injuries to their daughter Jane. They advocate for a life sentence without the possibility of release or appeal for Tsarnaev, arguing that pursuing the death penalty could lead to prolonged appeals and further pain for their family. The Richards emphasize their desire to move forward and end the ongoing anguish for themselves, Boston, and the country. The bombing incident killed three people, including Martin, and injured over 200 others. The sentencing phase for Tsarnaev is set to begin the day after the annual Boston Marathon and is expected to last four weeks.

This passage describes a Boeing 747 jumbo jet that has been transformed into a luxury home for a mystery billionaire at a cost of £400 million. Customized over three years, the jet, which can normally carry up to 600 passengers, now serves a single owner and can accommodate dozens of guests. The interior includes bedrooms, multiple lounges, a conference room, an onboard restaurant with a dining room and kitchen, and additional sleeping space in the 'aeroloft' on the top deck with eight full beds. Notable features also include a master bedroom with luxurious furnishings, an office or guest bedroom with porthole-style windows, and a state room with a desk. The design, depicted in artist's impressions by Greenpoint Technologies, mimics a high-end hotel rather than a typical airplane cabin, offering an exclusive and opulent flying experience far beyond standard first-class commercial flights.

SpaceX launched a Falcon 9 rocket carrying the uncrewed Dragon spacecraft from Cape Canaveral, Florida, to the International Space Station. While the Dragon successfully headed to the station to deliver over 4,300 pounds of supplies, including research equipment and an espresso maker, the attempt to land the rocket's first stage on a floating barge failed as it landed too hard and tipped over. This was SpaceX's second unsuccessful attempt at such a landing, with the goal being to reuse rockets to significantly reduce space access costs. The Dragon will be unpacked over five weeks by the station crew, then loaded with over 3,000 pounds of materials, including experiments and trash, for return to Earth, landing in the Pacific Ocean. This mission marks SpaceX's sixth to the station and the first private contractor to dock there. The launch, initially planned for Monday, was delayed to Tuesday due to weather.

Priscilla Presley, aged 69, will be a witness at the inaugural wedding at the new Elvis Presley's Graceland Wedding Chapel in Las Vegas, located inside the Westgate Hotel, formerly the Las Vegas Hilton where Elvis performed over 830 sold-out shows. This event is the result of a contest launched with NBC's Today show for an Elvis-obsessed couple, with the winners to be announced the following Monday and married on Thursday, April 23. The prize includes a free wedding reception, a two-night hotel suite stay, airfare, and tickets to the Elvis Experience theater show. Priscilla, who married Elvis in 1967, emphasized the seriousness and high quality of the chapel, explicitly banning impersonators. The chapel, part of the first permanent Graceland exhibit of Elvis's artifacts outside Memphis, was designed with input from Priscilla. Couples must submit videos or photos and an explanation of why they deserve to win this unique wedding opportunity.

Jordan Henderson, Liverpool's vice-captain, believes his team can close the four-point gap with Manchester City in the Premier League race for Champions League qualification, following a 2-0 victory over Newcastle United. Henderson and goalkeeper Simon Mignolet played their 47th game of the season in this match, matching the record for most appearances in Europe's top five leagues. Liverpool's recent win comes after disappointing performances against Manchester United and Arsenal, with Henderson expressing optimism about continuing their winning form. In the game, Raheem Sterling scored in the ninth minute, and Joe Allen added a second goal with 20 minutes remaining, securing the win despite a controversial non-penalty call involving Dejan Lovren and Ayoze Perez.

Roma broke their four-month home winless streak with a 1-0 victory over Napoli in a crucial Serie A match for Champions League qualification. Miralem Pjanic scored the decisive goal in the 25th minute from a counter-attack, while goalkeeper Morgan de Sanctis made several key saves in the second half to secure the win. This result moved second-place Roma four points ahead of Lazio, while Napoli, remaining in fifth, extended their winless streak to five games. Despite tight security due to past incidents and a ban on ticket sales to residents of the Campania region, no issues were reported. Roma played without key players Francesco Totti and Gervinho but managed to hold off Napoli, who had a potential penalty claim dismissed.

This passage discusses a lackluster season for Doncaster Rovers, a Yorkshire football team stuck in mid-table in League One. It describes a particularly uneventful match against Fleetwood Town at the Keepmoat Stadium, which ended in a 0-0 draw. The game was so devoid of action that the Doncaster media team struggled to compile highlights, ultimately producing a very brief 27-second video for the club's YouTube channel, featuring just 14 seconds of match action including the kick-off, a goal kick, and the final whistle.

Roland Giroux has developed a unique bond with his blood parrot cichlid, a hybrid fish first bred in Taiwan around 1986. In a video, Giroux is seen interacting with the fish by dipping his hand into the tank to stroke and massage it. The fish responds positively, relaxing and staying still during the interaction, often returning to Giroux's hand after briefly swimming away. It also shows affection by swimming up his arm and following his hand to the water's surface when he removes it. Giroux, who uploads many videos of his fish on YouTube, spends at least 15 minutes daily playing with the cichlid. Initially, the fish shared its tank with two others, but they were removed due to bullying. Through hand-feeding with frozen blood worms, Giroux helped the fish become more sociable, and it now shows frustration if not interacted with daily.

Ben Stokes, known for his fiery temperament in the England cricket team, returned to Kensington Oval, where he previously injured his wrist. Despite a minor back issue, Stokes is eager to play in Barbados. His aggressive style, evident in past confrontations like with Mitchell Johnson in the Ashes and a recent clash with Marlon Samuels, requires careful management. England coach Peter Moores has been instrumental in guiding Stokes on how to channel his aggression positively, as seen in his improved response after their discussion. England values Stokes' natural exuberance and aims to balance it without suppressing his spirit, hoping to maximize his contribution in runs and wickets. The team is keen on having Stokes play regularly alongside Chris Jordan to help both develop, despite considerations of team composition involving spinners like Adil Rashid.

The Euro 2016 qualifier match between Wales and Belgium, set for June 12 at Cardiff City Stadium, has sold out with 33,000 tickets. Both teams are top of Group B with 11 points from five games, though Belgium leads due to a better goal difference. This game is crucial for Wales, who are in their strongest position to qualify for a major tournament since 1958. Following a 3-0 win over Israel, excitement and expectations for Wales, led by Chris Coleman and featuring Gareth Bale, have surged. The match will be held at the preferred Cardiff City Stadium instead of the larger Millennium Stadium, adhering to UEFA rules and player preference for the more intimate venue.

England coach John Peacock has announced the squad for the upcoming UEFA European Under-17 Championship in Bulgaria. As defending champions, having won against Holland in last year's final, England qualified with a perfect record. They are in Group D with Holland, Italy, and the Republic of Ireland, starting their campaign against Italy on May 7 in Burgas. The squad includes promising players from Premier League clubs like Chelsea's Jay Dasilva and Ike Ugbo, and Arsenal's Chris Willock and Stephy Mavididi, with the latter two being first-time call-ups. Liverpool's Herbie Kane and Trent Arnold return after missing the Elite Round. England's other group matches are against Holland on May 10 and Ireland on May 13.

Manchester City are interested in signing 14-year-old Anderlecht playmaker Evangelos Patoulidis, who is considered one of the top talents from Anderlecht's youth system. Despite interest from Arsenal and Barcelona, Patoulidis previously declined a move to Barcelona's La Masia academy at age 12 to focus on his studies. Manchester City, under manager Manuel Pellegrini, have engaged in talks with Anderlecht chairman Roger Vanden Stock to negotiate a compensation package for the promising Belgian starlet as part of their strategy to build for the future.

Vanessa Santillan, a 33-year-old Mexican transgender escort, was found strangled and beaten to death in a £400,000 flat in Fulham, south west London, at the end of March. Her body was discovered on March 28 after the London Ambulance Service was called to the scene, where she was pronounced dead due to injuries to her head and neck. A 23-year-old man has been arrested in connection with her death but has been bailed and is required to return for further questioning. Santillan, who worked as an escort in London, Paris, and Miami, had moved to London from Mexico and expressed her love for London and Paris on social media prior to her death. Scotland Yard is appealing for information from anyone who had contact with her in the hours before her death, and the police are committed to solving the case, though they have not confirmed if her profession is central to the investigation.

Dawn, a woman who endured seven miscarriages, appeared on The Jeremy Kyle Show to confront her long-term friend and housemate, Jamie, a convicted burglar, for stealing £207 intended for a £500 gravestone for her deceased child, Daniel James. Despite initial denials from Jamie and his girlfriend Carol, a lie detector test confirmed Jamie's guilt. Additionally, Jamie had confessed to the theft in a Facebook message to Dawn, blaming Carol. Devastated by the betrayal, Dawn expressed her grief and anger, highlighting her intent to honor her son with the gravestone, before breaking down in tears and leaving the stage.

ISIS released over 200 Yazidis, a minority group in northern Iraq, who were captured during the terror organization's takeover of their towns last summer. The group of released individuals, mostly women, children, ill, and elderly, numbered between 217 and 228 according to different officials. The release was facilitated by Arab tribal leaders and the freed Yazidis were taken to Irbil by the Peshmerga forces. The motivation behind the release remains unclear. ISIS has previously released other Yazidis, mainly children and elderly, since their initial attacks. The Yazidis, a small religious community of Kurdish descent, have faced severe persecution, including mass killings and enslavement by ISIS, particularly after the conquest of Sinjar, which led to a major humanitarian crisis. An international coalition, including the United States, responded with aid, rescues, and airstrikes against ISIS. The Yazidi population in northern Iraq is estimated at 500,000, less than 1% of Iraq's total population.

Harry Kane, the Tottenham striker, has had a remarkable season, breaking into the first team and Roy Hodgson's England side. He is nominated for both the PFA Player and Young Player of the Season awards, competing against players like Eden Hazard and Alexis Sanchez. A new animation by Copa90 features Kane's best goals and celebrations, including strikes against Chelsea and Arsenal, and his England debut goal, using still photographs to create an animated effect. The video, titled 'Harry Kane - PFA Player of the Year?', was released ahead of the awards ceremony on Sunday.

Jamie Carragher supports Brendan Rodgers as the suitable manager for Liverpool despite a trophyless season and the likelihood of finishing outside the top four. Carragher, a former Liverpool defender, expressed this view after receiving a Beacon Award for his community work on Merseyside. He believes Rodgers' future shouldn't hinge on a single game and highlighted the challenges with new players integrating into the team. Liverpool, currently seven points behind fourth-placed Manchester City with a game in hand, are at risk of missing Champions League qualification. Carragher emphasized the need for correct signings to improve the team's performance and return to the top four, potentially winning a trophy next season. Additionally, Carragher's community efforts through his 23 Foundation involve coaching in schools in deprived areas of Merseyside, aiming to inspire and support local youth.

Four-year-old James Hayward had his toy nerf gun confiscated at East Midlands Airport after it was deemed a security risk by airport staff, who also frisked the child. The incident occurred as James and his parents, Phil and Hazel, were preparing to board a flight to Lanzarote. The toy, which fires sponge darts, was detected by X-ray machines, leading to its confiscation and a thorough security check of James. Phil Hayward criticized the security measures as 'ludicrous' and 'over-zealous,' especially given the time constraints and the number of passengers. After returning from their 10-day holiday, James was bought a replacement toy gun. East Midlands Airport apologized for the inconvenience, offered to mail the toy back to the family’s home in Doncaster, South Yorkshire, and defended their actions by stating that safety and security are their top priorities, adhering to government regulations which prohibit items resembling weapons, including replica or model guns, through security.

A 31-year-old man named Rich from Humpty Doo, Northern Territory, has posted an online advertisement on Gumtree seeking a girlfriend or wife. In the ad, he lists specific requirements for his ideal partner, including being a non-drinker and non-smoker, fit, attractive, reliable, honest, loyal, good at household tasks, cooking, and intimacy. She must also enjoy the outdoors and be a "princess" when needed. Rich describes himself as athletic, heavily tattooed, 175cm tall, well-endowed, successful, owning property, and financially generous, offering benefits like accommodation, a potential company car, phone, laptop, and gym membership to the successful candidate. He enjoys traveling, sports, fishing, and camping, and emphasizes his independence and willingness to spend money on his partner. Former partners are not eligible to apply, and all reasonable offers will be considered. Daily Mail Australia was unable to contact him.

Greg Dyke, chairman of the Football Association, is supported by five former England managers—Graham Taylor, Glenn Hoddle, Kevin Keegan, Sven-Goran Eriksson, and Steve McClaren—in his push for significant changes to increase the number of home-grown players in club squads from eight to 12. Dyke also proposes redefining 'home-grown' to mean training in England for three years before the age of 18, instead of 21. Despite opposition from the Premier League, the former managers have urged swift support for these proposals in a letter reported by the Daily Telegraph, warning that failure to adopt these changes could hinder England's competitiveness internationally and prolong the wait for a World Cup victory. They highlight the shrinking pool of English talent at top levels, with only 36.8% of recent Premier League starters eligible for England selection. However, they note positive developments with emerging talents like Ross Barkley, Raheem Sterling, and Harry Kane, emphasizing the need for more playing opportunities for young English players. England's recent performance, including a draw in Italy and a perfect record in Euro 2016 qualifiers under Roy Hodgson, also provides encouragement.

In the latest episode of the show, Demelza Poldark, played by Eleanor Tomlinson, quickly progresses from barely showing to giving birth to a baby daughter within minutes of the episode's start. Ross Poldark, portrayed by Aidan Turner, is shown as a devoted husband and father, deeply in love with Demelza, despite initially marrying her out of duty. The rapid timeline of Demelza's pregnancy, jumping from the announcement to being eight months pregnant and then to birth, mirrors a similar fast-paced pregnancy storyline with another character, Elizabeth, in a previous episode. This accelerated depiction of pregnancy has caught the attention of fans, with some humorously noting on Twitter that pregnancies in "Poldark times" seem to conclude in just 10 minutes. Ross, a popular heartthrob, is clearly off the market, much to the disappointment of many fans across the country.

Nigel Pearson, manager of Leicester, has emphasized the importance of his team focusing on their own performance rather than their relegation rivals as they fight to stay in the Barclays Premier League. Despite being at the bottom of the table, Leicester is just three points from safety following consecutive wins, including a dramatic 3-2 victory over West Brom with an injury-time goal by Jamie Vardy. Pearson cautions against over-optimism and distractions from external predictions, urging his team to control their destiny by concentrating on their upcoming matches, starting with hosting Swansea on Saturday.

A North Pacific gray whale named Varvara has set a record for the longest mammal migration, traveling nearly 14,000 miles from Russia's Sakhalin Island across the Pacific Ocean to Baja, Mexico. This journey, tracked by Oregon State University scientists, surpassed the previous record held by a humpback whale. Varvara's migration included visits to three major breeding areas for eastern gray whales, suggesting she might originate from Mexico. Initially thought to be an endangered western gray whale, her extensive travel challenges previous assumptions about genetic differences between eastern and western gray whales, prompting a need for further research. Bruce Mate, the study’s lead author and director of the Marine Mammal Institute at Oregon State University, highlighted the significance of her navigation skills and the potential reclassification of some western gray whales as eastern.

Overnight, a 1,000ft stretch of seabed surfaced along the Shiretoko Peninsula near Rausu on Japan's Hokkaido Island, rising up to 50ft above sea level and measuring 1,000-1,640ft long and 100ft wide. Geologists attribute this sudden emergence to a nearby landslide caused by melting ice and snow, which shifted the underwater area upwards. Local residents were surprised as there were no tremors or sounds indicating the land movement. Authorities, including a researcher and a government official, confirmed the event is unrelated to seismic activity, such as the recent earthquake in Kathmandu Valley, and do not expect further expansion of the landmass. Marine life, including seaweed and sea urchins, remains attached to the newly exposed land.

Gregory van der Wiel has refuted rumors of leaving Paris Saint-Germain (PSG) in the summer, expressing his deep affection for the club, city, and teammates. Despite a recent disagreement with manager Laurent Blanc over being dropped from a Champions League game against Chelsea, Van der Wiel remains content at PSG and is eager to sign a new contract. He acknowledges the coach's authority in team selections and is prepared to play when needed. Meanwhile, PSG is rumored to be interested in signing Barcelona's Dani Alves, which could impact Van der Wiel's future at the club.

Carlos Tevez, currently with Juventus, has expressed his desire to return to his former club, Boca Juniors in Argentina, this summer, despite his contract with Juventus lasting until the end of next season. Boca Juniors' president, Daniel Angelici, confirmed that they are close to finalizing Tevez's return, but stressed that Tevez must first terminate his contract with Juventus, which runs until 2016. Tevez, who has scored 17 goals this season and is the league's top scorer, shocked Juventus with his decision to leave, even as he is on track to win a second Serie A title and compete for European glory. Juventus, though reluctant, have accepted his decision and are looking for replacements. Tevez's international manager, Tata Martino, stated that the potential move would not affect Tevez's future with the Argentina national team, emphasizing that both Juventus and Boca Juniors are great teams. Tevez has always intended to end his career at Boca Juniors, where he started in their youth academy in 1996 and scored 26 league goals in 76 appearances before moving to Corinthians in 2005.

During a Champions League match at the Allianz Arena, Bayern Munich, managed by Pep Guardiola, achieved a stunning 6-1 victory over Porto, securing their place in the semi-finals. Bayern led 5-0 at half-time, with goals from Thiago Alcantara, Jerome Boateng, Thomas Muller, Xabi Alonso, and two from Robert Lewandowski, overturning Porto's initial 3-1 lead from the first leg in Portugal. Amid the excitement, Guardiola tore a hole in his trousers, exposing his underwear, and humorously remarked he’d need new ones for the next match. Bayern's dominant performance sent a strong message to their European rivals.

A multi-vehicle crash involving three cars occurred on the Brisbane Valley Highway, 2km south of Fernvale, in Brisbane's west, affecting ten people, including four children. A 40-year-old man and a five-year-old boy, both with chest-related injuries, were airlifted to Princess Alexandra Hospital. A 27-year-old woman with arm injuries and a six-year-old girl with abdominal pain were also flown to the hospital. Six others, including an infant and two young girls, were taken to Ipswich Hospital with minor injuries or for assessment. A man sustained hand lacerations, while two females were uninjured. One person was trapped in a vehicle and freed using hydraulic cutting gear. The highway is closed with diversions in place south of Fernvale, expected to last a few hours.

This weekend, a crucial Premier League match is set at the Emirates Stadium where second-placed Arsenal will face league leaders Chelsea on Sunday at 4pm. Arsenal's midfielder Mesut Ozil, who has scored four goals in 25 matches this season, is anticipated to start. Ozil recently acquired a new Apple Watch, priced between £299 and £13,500, and shared his excitement on Instagram, comparing it to a gadget from the TV show Knight Rider. Arsenal, trailing Chelsea by 10 points with six games left, are uplifted by the return of Jack Wilshere, who was on the bench during their recent FA Cup semi-final win against Reading after a five-month injury hiatus. Arsenal legend Ray Parlour praises Wilshere’s potential, emphasizing his skill in bypassing players and linking up play, but raises concerns about his recurring injuries, questioning if he can maintain fitness for a full season, a challenge also faced by teammate Abou Diaby.

Mark Clattenburg will referee the upcoming Manchester derby at Old Trafford between Manchester United and Manchester City, despite having sent off three players from both teams this season. Notably, he dismissed City captain Vincent Kompany during a recent international match, leading to Kompany's suspension for an upcoming game. In the Premier League, Clattenburg has issued red cards to two United players, Tyler Blackett and Luke Shaw, in matches against Leicester and West Ham, respectively. Although previously accused of bias towards United, Clattenburg is recognized as a top Premier League referee. The derby is crucial as United, riding a five-game winning streak, recently surpassed City in the standings after City's loss to Crystal Palace, intensifying the battle for second place behind likely champions Chelsea. Clattenburg will be supported by assistants Simon Beck and Jake Collin, with Jonathan Moss as the fourth official.

Bob Katter, a federal MP of Lebanese descent, has stirred controversy by accusing the Queensland Government of treating embattled MP Billy Gordon as a "little black puppet on a string." Katter claims the government assumed Gordon would resign after accusations of domestic violence and revelations of his criminal past, which led to Gordon's exit from the Queensland Labor Party. Despite quitting the party, Gordon decided to remain in parliament as an independent, disrupting the government's slim majority. Katter, drawing from his own experiences with racism, criticized the government's assumptions and defended his provocative terminology, citing personal identification with racial issues. His statement has drawn mixed reactions on social media, with some questioning his choice of words. Katter also referenced other federal MPs to argue against the expectation of resignation and to emphasize Gordon's resolve to maintain independence.

Dayna Dobias, a 19-year-old from Downers Grove, Illinois, born with cerebral palsy, is using dance to challenge stereotypes and inspire others. Despite facing bullying and judgment due to her disability, Dayna has created several dance videos, including one to Taylor Swift's "Shake It Off," to show that she is not so different from others and to counteract misconceptions about disabilities. She aims to change how people with disabilities are represented in television, film, and fashion industries. Additionally, Dayna has overcome significant challenges, as doctors initially thought she might never walk, yet she now dances, drives, and attends college like her peers. She has also started motivational speaking at local schools in the Chicago area to turn negativity into positivity and encourage others to look beyond her disability.

Orlando City, an MLS team with a significant Latin-American fanbase, has shown interest in signing Manchester United's Javier Hernandez, who has struggled during his loan at Real Madrid. Coached by Adrian Heath and captained by Kaka, Orlando sees Hernandez as a major commercial asset. However, Hernandez is also attracting attention from eight European clubs, including Southampton, Stoke, West Ham, Everton, Wolfsburg, AC Milan, Lazio, and Inter Milan, with Manchester United open to selling him for around £8 million. Meanwhile, Manchester United has offered a revised contract to 19-year-old prospect Andreas Pereira, who has drawn interest from Paris St Germain, Juventus, PSV Eindhoven, and Feyenoord after rejecting the initial offer.

Early Saturday morning around 12:15am, at a 76 Station in South Los Angeles, a gang of at least three individuals poured gasoline on a white Dodge Charger and set it on fire after an argument with the driver, who was pumping gas. The incident escalated from an attempted carjacking, during which the suspects threatened the driver with a gun, causing him to flee. They then doused the car with gasoline and ignited it, despite two passengers being inside. Fortunately, no one was injured, though the car's front end was completely destroyed. The Los Angeles County Fire Department is investigating the event as arson, using surveillance video, while the suspects remain at large.

A chiropractor from southern Iowa, Charles Manuel of Lamoni, has surrendered his state license after being accused of accepting sex as payment for services and performing exorcisms on patients. According to a report by the Iowa Board of Chiropractic, Manuel signed an agreement admitting to these misdeeds and agreed not to seek reinstatement for at least 10 years. He must also prove that the circumstances leading to his license revocation no longer exist before resuming practice. Additionally, Manuel advised patients to stop taking prescribed medication. Despite these issues, he has received highly positive patient satisfaction ratings on HealthGrades.com, with a perfect five-star rating from three survey responses. His practice was listed at a residential address in Lamoni, and he no longer works at his former practice location.

A Russian SU-27 Flanker intercepted a U.S. RC-135U reconnaissance plane over the Baltic Sea in international airspace north of Poland on Tuesday, in what the Pentagon described as an "unsafe and unprofessional" manner due to aggressive maneuvers and high speed in close proximity. The U.S. disputes Russian claims that the U.S. plane's transponder was off and is filing a complaint through diplomatic channels with Moscow. This incident echoes a similar dangerous encounter a year ago over the Sea of Okhotsk. Such encounters between Russian and U.S. aircraft are frequent in Northern Europe and the Russian Far East to Alaska region.

An FBI agent's sniper rifle was stolen from his car in a Salt Lake City hotel parking lot at the Marriott Springhill Suites just days before President Obama's visit to Utah. The rifle, secured in a hard case with padlocks and chains inside the car, was taken by breaking the rear passenger-side window and using a rope and vehicle momentum to forcibly remove the case. Additional items, including a gear bag, backpack, clothing, and tools, were also stolen during the overnight theft on March 27. While some of the agent's belongings were recovered nearby, the sniper rifle remains missing. Evidence at the scene included skid marks, rope pieces, and the broken rifle case handle. The hotel lacks surveillance cameras, and the rifle's serial number has been entered into the National Crime Information Computer. The Secret Service was informed of the theft before Obama's visit but did not comment on security adjustments. Police are unsure if the agent's car was specifically targeted.

Luigi Costa, a 71-year-old man, is accused of murdering his elderly neighbor, Terrence Freebody, in July 2012 in Canberra by stomping on his head, cutting his throat, and stabbing him multiple times. Forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Mullen, who examined Costa post-incident, testified that Costa was likely suffering from dementia and alcohol abuse, which compromised his brain and led to a confused state during the murder. Evidence of Costa's declining mental state was supported by fluctuating moods during emergency calls and physical signs of confusion at the crime scene. Professor Mullen believes Costa did not understand his actions or their consequences due to his mental condition. The prosecution suggested Costa might have feigned memory loss, a claim Mullen denied. Costa's mental state is crucial to the case, as the jury could return a not guilty verdict if his unstable mindset at the time of the attack is proven.

In a 1-0 victory against Burnley at Goodison Park, Everton's Ross Barkley missed a 10th-minute penalty, which was awarded for a foul on Aaron Lennon. Despite Leighton Baines, a successful penalty taker with 15 goals from 16 attempts in the Premier League, being on the field, Barkley took the shot and it was saved by Burnley goalkeeper Tom Heaton. Manager Roberto Martinez defended Barkley's decision, stating he was fine with multiple players taking penalties based on their confidence at the moment, and noted Baines was supportive. The miss did not cost Everton the game as Kevin Mirallas scored the winning goal in the 29th minute. This incident recalled a previous penalty miss by Mirallas against West Brom when he took the ball from Baines.

Two passengers were found dead in their stateroom on the Holland America Line's ms Ryndam cruise ship at 11:30 a.m. on Thursday in San Juan, Puerto Rico, in what appears to be a murder-suicide. The ship, which departed from Tampa, Florida, on March 29 for a 14-day Southern Caribbean cruise, had its cabin secured immediately after the discovery, and authorities, including the FBI, were notified. The FBI and local authorities are investigating, with Holland America fully cooperating. The bodies were discovered by the ship's cleaning staff after they knocked on the cabin door.

Patrick Kluivert, former Holland forward and assistant coach, has successfully led Curacao to the second round of CONCACAF qualifying for the 2018 World Cup. Under Kluivert's guidance, Curacao secured a 4-3 aggregate victory over Montserrat, with a crucial goal by Charlton Vicento in the 87th minute of the second leg, which ended in a 2-2 draw. The team had previously won the first leg 2-1 in Willemstad. Curacao is set to face Cuba in the next round on June 8 and 16. Kluivert, who has familial ties to Curacao through his mother, was a World Cup semi-finalist as a player in 1998 and served as an assistant coach under Louis van Gaal in 2014.

Esteban Cambiasso, a seasoned footballer with an illustrious career including 15 trophies at Inter Milan and titles at Real Madrid and River Plate, now plays for Leicester City in the Premier League. Despite Leicester being seven points from safety at the bottom of the table with only eight games left, Cambiasso remains optimistic about avoiding relegation. He equates saving Leicester from the drop to winning a major trophy, emphasizing the significance of this challenge. Having signed a one-year deal with Leicester, he has become a key player and expresses contentment with his life in the East Midlands, hinting at a possible extension beyond his current contract. Cambiasso and his team, who haven't won since January, are set to face West Ham United, and he believes they still have a chance to secure crucial points to remain in the Premier League.

A 23-year-old mother named Gemma risks being banned from seeing her two children under five, whom she handed over to her 52-year-old mother Debbie at four months old. Debbie, who has raised the children since then, is considering the ban due to Gemma's persistent drinking, partying, and use of the legal high MKat, as well as suspicions of theft, including an iPad allegedly sold to fund her lifestyle. Despite denying the iPad theft, Gemma admits to past stealing from her mother. Debbie, frustrated and distrustful, feels Gemma is unfit to care for the children, prioritizing her party lifestyle over motherhood. After appearing on The Jeremy Kyle Show and confirming Gemma's deceit through a lie detector test, Debbie is prepared to prohibit Gemma from her home and contact with the children, whom she loves deeply and who call her 'mum'.

In a match at Stamford Bridge, Chelsea's Eden Hazard scored to give his team a 1-0 lead over Manchester United. The goal followed a controversial challenge by Chelsea captain John Terry on United striker Radamel Falcao, which led to Falcao losing the ball near the halfway line. Chelsea's Cesc Fabregas picked up the loose ball, initiating the play that resulted in Hazard's goal via a back-heel from Oscar. Sky Sports pundits Thierry Henry, Jamie Redknapp, and Graeme Souness criticized the play during half-time, asserting that Terry's rough tackle, described as a forearm smash with an elbow to Falcao's head, was a clear foul that should have stopped play. While Redknapp noted Falcao could have been stronger, all agreed the challenge warranted a foul call.

Hillary Scott of Lady Antebellum and her team were safely evacuated when their tour bus caught fire on a Texas freeway near Dallas on Thursday morning. The incident, captured on video by Michael Barnett and shared on CNN iReport, occurred after a rear tire blew out, leading to the bus bursting into flames on Interstate 30. Scott, her husband, the tour manager, and the driver escaped unharmed. Scott expressed gratitude for their safety on Instagram, noting that while the fire destroyed the back lounge of the bus, her Bible was spared. The other band members, Charles Kelley and Dave Haywood, were not on the bus. Lady Antebellum is scheduled to perform at the 50th Academy of Country Music Awards in Arlington, Texas, on Sunday.

Dr. Adrian Quarterman from Dundee University is developing a space laser system that could potentially power homes by converting sunlight into laser energy using satellites equipped with mirrors. These satellites would orbit Earth, harvest sunlight, convert it into laser light via semiconductors, and transmit the energy back to Earth to boost solar panels. This could make solar power viable in less sunny regions like Scotland and provide instant power to disaster-stricken areas. Initial trials in Scotland were successful, with plans to continue testing in Portugal. Unlike powerful sci-fi lasers, these will not be strong enough for destructive purposes. Separately, Tokyo researchers have proposed a laser system for the International Space Station to clear space debris by pushing it into Earth's atmosphere to burn up, targeting debris less than a centimeter in size. Dr. Quarterman notes a minor concern about control over his satellites, though the lasers are not weaponizable.

Stephen Munden, a 54-year-old convicted paedophile with a 'fanatical obsession' with young girls, has escaped from a psychiatric unit near Hook, Hampshire. He was last seen leaving the hospital at 6:15pm on Tuesday. Munden, who is 5ft 8ins tall, of heavy build, with dark hair, and possibly clean-shaven, was detained under the Mental Health Act following his conviction for sexually touching a three-year-old girl on a bus and possessing indecent images of children. He has a history of denying the contact offense, claiming it was accidental, and suffers from autism and mild learning difficulties. Authorities have launched a manhunt and are urgently seeking information on his whereabouts.

A Los Angeles judge ordered V. Stiviano, the former companion of Donald Sterling, to return over $2.6 million in gifts after a lawsuit by Sterling's wife, Rochelle "Shelly" Sterling. Shelly accused Stiviano of exploiting wealthy older men, claiming Donald used their joint funds to lavish Stiviano with luxury cars and a $1.8 million duplex. Stiviano denied any wrongdoing, asserting the gifts were given freely by Donald, the former owner of the Los Angeles Clippers. Shelly Sterling celebrated the court ruling as a victory for recovering the funds and setting a legal precedent for spouses to reclaim such gifts. Donald Sterling's downfall was triggered by a leaked audio where he made racist remarks to Stiviano about her social media posts with African-Americans, including Magic Johnson. Consequently, NBA Commissioner Adam Silver banned Sterling from the league, fined him $2.5 million, and terminated his ownership rights in the Clippers franchise.

Thierry Henry, a former Arsenal player and current Sky Sports pundit, has criticized Arsenal's transfer activities and performance following their goalless draw with Chelsea. He insists that Arsenal must acquire four key players—a goalkeeper, a centre back, a defensive midfielder, and a top-quality striker—to contend for the Barclays Premier League title. Henry specifically doubts the capability of current striker Olivier Giroud to lead Arsenal to a championship, despite Giroud's 14 league goals this season. He compares Arsenal's needs to Chelsea's successful signings of players like Thibaut Courtois, Nemanja Matic, Cesc Fabregas, and Diego Costa, which bolstered their title-winning prospects. Arsenal currently stand third in the Premier League, level on points with Manchester City but with a game in hand. Henry emphasizes the necessity for competitive signings to instill a winning mentality within the team.

A young woman, a victim of years of abuse by Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, shared the profound impact of the abuse on her life during a court session in Sydney's District Court. Van Ryn, a wealthy NSW businessman, has pleaded guilty to 12 sex offences, including persistent sexual abuse of a child. The victim, who remains anonymous, expressed fear for future relationships and confusion over why she was targeted, revealing she was unaware the abuse was wrong at the time. She kept the abuse a secret until learning Van Ryn had been caught, after which she spoke out, despite fears of public knowledge and the lasting effects on her interactions with men. She has also struggled with depression, self-harm, and attempted suicide since the age of 14. Van Ryn remained impassive in court as she spoke. The hearing is ongoing.

Serge Gnabry, a 19-year-old Arsenal midfielder, is recovering from a serious knee injury that sidelined him since March 2014, following a match against Bayern Munich in the Champions League. Having impressed last season, his progress was halted by the injury. Recently, Gnabry played a full 90 minutes for Arsenal Under 21s in a 1-0 loss to Reading, marking his second full game in a week. He reports feeling 'better and better' and is optimistic about his return to play, now being over his injury concerns.

Jacob Phillips, a 23-year-old accountant and university graduate, tragically died after falling 70ft down a cliff in Penarth, South Wales. The incident occurred in December when Phillips, after a night out drinking in Cardiff with friends, attempted to evade a taxi fare due to lack of funds. He and his friends planned to use an ATM as a pretext before running from the taxi. In the darkness, Phillips leapt over a fence and fell off the cliff at the disused Northern Promenade. The taxi driver, unaware of the danger, did not pursue further. Phillips' body was discovered the next morning by a dog walker on the rocky beach below. The coroner recorded a verdict of accidental death, noting that Phillips likely became disoriented and was unaware of the sheer drop beyond the fence. Phillips, who worked for Pretty Green and had studied accountancy at the University of Birmingham, was in Wales for Christmas, staying with his mother in Cowbridge.

Last summer, thousands of holidaymakers faced significant delays in receiving their passports due to a backlog at HM Passport Office, which struggled to process 3.6 million applications, with over half a million stuck by mid-June. Despite the chaos, the agency made a £42.3 million profit and its managers received bonuses up to £3,500. However, very little compensation was provided to affected families, with only 2,191 claims approved, totaling £203,066, averaging £92.68 per claim.
