Ministers rejected blanket refunds and compensation demands from the Home Affairs Select Committee, citing the creation of a precedent. Keith Vaz, chairman of the committee, expressed astonishment at the low compensation numbers. Many holidaymakers, including Mathew Bean and Hayley Kirkham who lost £1,500 on a trip, received no reimbursement despite paying extra for fast-track services and missing their travel plans.

A 1930s timewarp home in Horfield, Bristol, untouched for over 80 years, is up for sale with a guide price of £200,000 to £250,000. This semi-detached property retains original features such as stained-glass windows with ship and coat of arms designs, oil-fired central heating, a mint green and black bathroom, wood-panelled hallway, and vintage kitchen cupboards. Additional nostalgic elements include retro food jars and tins like Cadbury’s Marvel dried milk and Colman’s Mustard on hallway shelves. Despite some upgrades like double glazing, the high cost of potential renovations might deter developers. Auctioneers suggest it could be an ideal family home for antique enthusiasts. The house will be auctioned on April 30 at the County Ground in Bristol.

The film "Shooter" (2007) and the TV series of the same name both center on Bob Lee Swagger, a skilled marksman and Force Recon veteran. In the TV series, Swagger, played by Ryan Phillippe, lives in exile but is drawn back into action upon discovering a plot to assassinate the president.

Charles Manson was convicted in 1971 of first-degree murder and conspiracy to commit murder for the deaths of seven people, including actress Sharon Tate, as well as for the murders of Gary Hinman and Donald "Shorty" Shea. Sir Donald George "Don" Bradman, AC, born on 27 August 1908 and passed away on 25 February 2001, was an Australian cricketer known as "The Don." James VI and I, born on 19 June 1566, was King of Scotland from 24 July 1567 and became King of England and Ireland from 24 March 1603 until his death on 27 March 1625. He ruled both Scotland and England as separate sovereign states in a personal union, each with its own parliament, judiciary, and laws. James advocated for a single parliament for both nations. While he achieved many of his goals in Scotland, he encountered significant challenges in England, including the Gunpowder Plot of 1605 and frequent conflicts with the English Parliament.

Big Brother 2017, also referred to as Big Brother 18, is the eighteenth series of the British reality TV show Big Brother, hosted by Emma Willis and narrated by Marcus Bentley. The Free State of Saxony is a landlocked federal state in Germany, bordering several other German states and the countries of Poland and the Czech Republic. It is the tenth largest of Germany's sixteen states, covering an area of 18,413 km², and the sixth most populous with 4 million residents. Saxony has a history spanning over a millennium and is located in a historically German-speaking region of Europe. Additionally, Saxony is known for its quality wine production, being one of the northernmost wine regions in Europe alongside Saale-Unstrut, and both are the only wine regions in the former East Germany.

Mel B. Brown started her solo career by releasing the single "I Want You Back" in collaboration with Missy Elliott on Virgin Records.

Released on July 1, 1994, it became the second highest-grossing Indian film of that year. The movie received nine Filmfare nominations in 1995. The film is also notable for its popular chartbuster songs.
"Hourglass" is a song by the British electronic duo Disclosure, and it is also the title of singer-songwriter James Taylor's fourteenth studio album.

Lopez then married Marc Anthony and enjoyed success with the film "Shall We Dance?" She had twins in 2008 and, following a less successful period, made a comeback in 2011 as a judge on "American Idol" and with the hit single "On the Floor," one of the best-selling singles ever.

A working animal is typically a domesticated animal trained by humans to perform various tasks. These tasks can include acting as guide or assistance dogs, providing tractive force like draft horses or logging elephants, or assisting with milking or herding through human encouragement. While wild animals can occasionally be tamed and trained for work, they are usually used for novelty or entertainment and often lack the trustworthiness and mild temperament of domesticated working animals.

"Vedam" is a 2010 Telugu language Indian drama film directed by Radhakrishna Jagarlamudi. It features a prominent cast including Allu Arjun, Manoj Manchu, Anushka Shetty, Manoj Bajpayee, Saranya Ponvannan, Deeksha Seth, Lekha Washington, and Siya Gautham.

Juventus has worn black and white striped kits since 1903 and currently plays at the Juventus Stadium, which has a capacity of 41,507.

Viola Davis played supporting and minor roles in various films and TV series during the late 1990s and early 2000s. Her notable works from this period include the films "Kate & Leopold" (2001) and "Far from Heaven" (2002), as well as the television series "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit."

Morse code is a telecommunication method that encodes text as a series of on-off tones, lights, or clicks, understandable by skilled individuals without special equipment. It is designed for efficiency, with character lengths inversely related to their frequency in English, enhancing communication speed. Morse code remains effective under poor signal conditions and doesn't require a decoding device, unlike voice communication. It is widely used by amateur radio repeaters for identification and can be employed in emergencies using simple, improvised methods, highlighting its simplicity and versatility.

The passage discusses the history of Earth, noting that volcanic outgassing likely formed the primordial atmosphere and ocean, which initially lacked oxygen and was toxic to most current life forms. Martin Van Buren, born on December 5, 1782, and died on July 24, 1862, was the eighth President of the United States from 1837 to 1841. "Underdog" is a film directed by Frederik Du Chau and written by Joe Piscatella, Adam Rifkin, and Craig A. Williams. It features a cast including Jim Belushi, Peter Dinklage, John Slattery, and Patrick Warburton, along with voice performances by Jason Lee, Amy Adams, and Brad Garrett.

"The 100" is a TV series that tracks a group of teenagers, including Clarke Griffin, Bellamy Blake, and others, who are among the first to return to Earth from a space habitat called "The Ark" following a catastrophic nuclear apocalypse. The show also features key adult characters from the Ark, such as Dr. Abby Griffin, Clarke’s mother; Marcus Kane, a council member; and Thelonious Jaha, the Chancellor and father of Wells Jaha, one of the teens.

The Concert for Bangladesh, despite later financial issues due to its pioneering approach, is celebrated as a successful and influential humanitarian aid project. It raised significant awareness and funds, and offered valuable lessons and inspiration for subsequent initiatives like Live Aid.
Mani Ratnam is recognized as one of India's influential filmmakers, credited with revolutionizing the Tamil film industry and significantly changing the landscape of Indian cinema.

The Freeport Doctrine was introduced by Stephen A. Douglas during the second of the Lincoln-Douglas debates on August 27, 1858, in Freeport, Illinois. These debates, known as The Great Debates of 1858, consisted of seven discussions between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate from Illinois, and the incumbent Senator Stephen Douglas of the Democratic Party. The debates, particularly those in Freeport, Quincy, and Alton, attracted large crowds from neighboring states due to the critical national issue of slavery.

"Easy A" is a 2010 American teen comedy film directed by Will Gluck and written by Bert V. Royal. It features a cast including Emma Stone, Stanley Tucci, Patricia Clarkson, Thomas Haden Church, Dan Byrd, Amanda Bynes, Penn Badgley, Cam Gigandet, Lisa Kudrow, and Aly Michalka.

Anne Rice, born Howard Allen Frances O'Brien on October 4, 1941, is an American author known for her work in gothic fiction, Christian literature, and erotica. She started her professional writing with "Interview with the Vampire" in 1976 while living in California and continued with sequels in the 1980s. Initially receiving mixed reviews, her popularity with critics and readers grew during the 1980s. She was married to Stan Rice, a poet and painter, from 1961 until his death from brain cancer in 2002 at the age of 60.

Camden is a city located in Camden County, New Jersey, with a population of 77,344 as per the 2010 United States Census. It is the 12th most populous municipality in New Jersey. Historically, at the start of the twentieth century, the city's population was predominantly made up of European immigrants.
Bret Easton Ellis wrote the screenplay for the 2013 film *The Canyons*, an American erotic thriller-drama directed by Paul Schrader. The film, an original work by Ellis, received critical derision.

The Lincoln-Douglas Debates, also known as The Great Debates of 1858, consisted of seven debates between Abraham Lincoln, the Republican candidate for the U.S. Senate from Illinois, and Stephen Douglas, the incumbent Democratic Senator. These debates took place in seven different towns across Illinois.

Homer, known in ancient Greek as Hómēros, is traditionally recognized as the author of the Iliad and the Odyssey, two foundational epic poems of ancient Greek literature. Additionally, The Thicket is a mystery/suspense novel by American author Joe R. Lansdale.
Christopher Scott Kyle, a U.S. Navy SEAL veteran and sniper, was born on April 8, 1974, and was murdered on February 2, 2013, by Eddie Ray Routh at a shooting range near Chalk Mountain, Texas.

Audioslave was a four-piece rock band formed by Soundgarden's lead singer/rhythm guitarist Chris Cornell and Rage Against the Machine members Tom Morello (lead guitar), Tim Commerford (bass/backing vocals), and Brad Wilk (drums), active from 2001 to 2007. Brad Wilk, also known for his role as the drummer in Rage Against the Machine from 1991-2000 and 2007-2011, started his career with Greta in 1990 and co-founded Rage Against the Machine in 1991 with Morello and Zack de la Rocha. Rage Against the Machine includes de la Rocha (rapper/vocalist), Commerford (bassist/backing vocalist), Morello (guitarist), and Wilk (drummer). As of 2016, Wilk, along with Commerford and Morello, is part of Prophets of Rage, which also features Chuck D, B-Real, and DJ Lord.

Janelle Monáe Robinson, born on December 1, 1985, is an American singer, songwriter, actress, and model. She is signed to her own label, Wondaland Arts Society, and Atlantic Records. In 2010, she released her first full-length studio album, The ArchAndroid, which is a critically acclaimed concept album and a sequel to her initial EP, released under Bad Boy Records.
Winter's Tale is a novel published in 1983, written by Mark Helprin.

Lake Providence is a town and the parish seat of East Carroll Parish in northeastern Louisiana, United States. Additionally, the passage mentions the University of Mississippi, where about 55 percent of undergraduates and 60 percent of the total student body are from Mississippi, 23 percent are minorities, and international students represent 90 different countries.
The series "Flaked" was renewed for a six-episode second season in July 2016, with the premiere scheduled for June 2, 2017.

Aaron Burr served in multiple significant political roles, including two terms in the New York State Assembly (1784-1785, 1798-1799), as New York State Attorney General (1789-1791), and as a U.S. Senator from New York (1791-1797). The peak of his career was his tenure as Vice President of the United States.

The Soyuz rocket, part of the Soviet space program, was designed in the 1960s by the Korolyov Design Bureau (now RKK Energia) to launch Soyuz spacecraft. Initially used for 8 unmanned test flights, it later facilitated the first 19 manned launches. The spacecraft, named "Soyuz" meaning "Union," succeeded the Voskhod spacecraft and was originally developed for the Soviet manned lunar programs. It remains in service today.
Steve Ditko studied under Batman artist Jerry Robinson at the Cartoonist and Illustrators School in New York City.

Rage Against the Machine, an American rap metal band, faced internal tensions leading to vocalist Zack de la Rocha's departure and the band's breakup in 2000. De la Rocha pursued a solo career, while the remaining members formed Audioslave with Chris Cornell, releasing three albums before disbanding in 2007. That same year, Rage Against the Machine reunited and performed at the Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival, marking their first performance together in seven years. Additionally, their fourth studio album, "Renegades," was released on December 5, 2000, by Epic Records.

The S&P BSE SENSEX, also known as BSE 30 or SENSEX, is a free-float market-weighted stock market index comprising 30 well-established and financially sound companies listed on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE). Tata Motors is one of these companies and is also listed on the National Stock Exchange of India and the New York Stock Exchange.

Vietnam, officially known as the Socialist Republic of Vietnam, is located on the easternmost part of the Indochina Peninsula in Southeast Asia. It is the 14th most populous country globally and the 9th in Asia, with a population of about 92.7 million. Vietnam shares borders with China to the north, Laos and Cambodia to the west, and has maritime boundaries with Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Indonesia. Since 2000, it has experienced one of the highest economic growth rates worldwide, and in 2011, it topped the Global Growth Generators Index among 11 major economies. Vietnam is also one of the few remaining one-party socialist states that officially practices communism.
"Dreamer" is a 2005 American sports drama film, marking the directorial debut of John Gatins, who also wrote the screenplay.

Bhagat Singh was a charismatic Indian socialist revolutionary who became a folk hero of the Indian independence movement due to his two acts of dramatic violence against the British in India and his execution at the age of 23 on March 23, 1931. His actions and subsequent death significantly increased his popularity and cemented his status as a symbol of resistance.

Aparshakti Khurana made his Bollywood debut in the 2016 Indian Hindi-language biographical sports drama film "Dangal," directed by Nitesh Tiwari and starring Aamir Khan. The film focuses on a wrestling competition.

James VI and I, born on 19 June 1566, was King of Scotland from 24 July 1567 as James VI, and became King of England and Ireland as James I from 24 March 1603 until his death on 27 March 1625. He ruled both Scotland and England in personal union after the crowns united in 1603, although each kingdom retained its own parliament, judiciary, and laws. James advocated for a single parliament for both nations and faced numerous challenges with the English Parliament during his reign.

Danielle Cormack, born on December 26, 1970, is a New Zealand stage and screen actress. She was an original cast member of the soap opera Shortland Street and gained recognition for roles such as Ephiny in Xena: Warrior Princess, Cynthia Ross in The Cult, Shota in Legend of the Seeker, and Kate Leigh in Underbelly: Razor. She also appeared in the 2009 film Separation City and the Australian series Rake. Her most notable recent role was as Bea Smith in the prison drama Wentworth, where she starred for four years until 2016.
Rob Sheridan, born on October 11, 1979, is an American graphic designer, director, and photographer, primarily recognized for his significant contributions to the band Nine Inch Nails.

David Spade is an actor who has starred and co-starred in several films including "Tommy Boy," "Black Sheep," "Joe Dirt," "Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser," "Grown Ups," and "Grown Ups 2." Specifically, "Joe Dirt 2: Beautiful Loser" is a 2015 American comedy film directed by Fred Wolf and co-written by David Spade and Fred Wolf.
Angela Evelyn Bassett is an American actress born on August 16, 1958.

"Artpop," an album by Lady Gaga, garnered mixed reviews from music critics. Despite the varied critical reception, it achieved commercial success by debuting at number one on the US Billboard 200, selling 258,000 copies in its first week. This marked Gaga's second consecutive number-one album in the US, with total sales reaching 757,000 copies. Globally, "Artpop" was the ninth best-selling album of 2013, with 2.3 million copies sold.

In 2006, John Frusciante released his fifth and final album with the Red Hot Chili Peppers, titled *Stadium Arcadium*. This album marked his last contribution to the band, as he officially left in 2009.

Margaret Thatcher, as Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, introduced policies known as Thatcherism. She is recognized as one of the most influential politicians in British history, though her policies remain a subject of ongoing debate and controversy.

Michael Andrew "Duff" McKagan, born on February 5, 1964, is an American musician, singer, songwriter, and author. Beyond his music career, he has also made a name for himself as a writer, contributing weekly columns on various topics to SeattleWeekly.com, Playboy.com, and ESPN.com.
Tom Baker, an English actor, has a diverse career that includes acting roles as well as narrating commercials, video games, audiobooks, and television series.

Valencia, officially known as València, is the capital of the autonomous community of Valencia in Spain. It is the third largest city in Spain, following Madrid and Barcelona, with approximately 800,000 residents in its administrative center. The metropolitan area of Valencia is also the third largest in Spain, with a population between 1.7 and 2.5 million. The Valencian Community, also referred to as the Valencian Country, is an autonomous region of Spain.
Buffy Summers is a character portrayed by Kristy Swanson in the film and by Sarah Michelle Gellar in the television series.
The TV series "Make It or Break It" concluded with its third season, as announced on April 26, 2012. The series finale was broadcast on May 14, 2012.

Speech recognition (SR) is a sub-field of computational linguistics that focuses on developing technologies to convert spoken language into text using computers. It integrates expertise from linguistics, computer science, and electrical engineering. Applications of SR include voice dialing, call routing, appliance control, search functions, data entry, document preparation, speech-to-text processing, and aircraft voice input. The field has seen significant advancements, demonstrated by a surge in academic papers and the global industry adoption of deep learning methods by major companies such as Google, Microsoft, IBM, Baidu, Apple, Amazon, Nuance, SoundHound, IflyTek, and CDAC, who base their SR systems on this technology.

Richard Alf, born on January 26, 1952, and passed away on January 4, 2012, was an American businessman and former comic book store owner. He co-founded the San Diego Comic-Con International, originally named the Golden State Comic Book Convention in 1970, alongside Shel Dorf, Ken Krueger, and Mike Towry. Alf also served as the chairman of the event starting in 1970. The convention was later renamed the San Diego Comic Book Convention.
"Fist of Legend" is a remake of the 1972 film "Fist of Fury," originally starring Bruce Lee as the main character.

France's Dubuisson scored a 67, tying with South Africa's Van Zyl at 16 under par. Rory McIlroy, with a third consecutive 67, reached 15 under par alongside Thailand's Kiradech Aphibarnrat, highlighted by an eagle on the 12th hole. McIlroy, a four-time major winner from Northern Ireland, is aiming for his first title since May and expressed confidence in achieving a lower score in the upcoming round. Despite early setbacks in the round, including dropped shots on the third and 10th holes, he recovered with a birdie and an eagle. After recovering from an ankle injury sustained in July, McIlroy returned to competition, including an unsuccessful defense of his US PGA title and a 26th place tie in the Frys.com Open. He is currently leading England's Danny Willett by 271,214 points in the Race to Dubai with three events left after the Turkish Open. English players Chris Wood and Richard Bland are positioned fifth and seventh respectively.

Sheikh Ali Salman, speaking to the BBC, emphasized the need for meaningful national dialogue in Bahrain, urging the government to offer "concrete solutions" and for a representative of the royal family to engage in talks. He highlighted the internal division within the royal court, with reformist Crown Prince Salman al-Khalifa favoring dialogue, while hardliners, led by Prime Minister Sheikh Khalifa bin Salman al-Khalifa, resist concessions fearing escalated opposition demands. Despite skepticism from young protesters, Sheikh Salman advocates for collaboration with reformists in the royal family and recalls a thwarted seven-point plan for constitutional monarchy agreed with the Crown Prince just before GCC troops intervened on March 14, 2011. He expressed hope for stronger US involvement under Senator John Kerry and criticized the UK's private approach to urging reform, insisting on public pressure. Additionally, Sheikh Salman reaffirmed al-Wefaq's commitment to peaceful demonstrations despite bans and called for the release of imprisoned opposition leaders and activists to ensure successful dialogue.

Christopher Hogwood, a pivotal figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, leading it for 30 years across six continents and producing over 200 CDs, including the first complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments. Notable recordings include the 1980 version of Handel's Messiah, recognized as a top recording by BBC Music Magazine. Hogwood, who studied keyboard at Cambridge University, held various prestigious positions, including artistic director roles and academic posts at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell Universities. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned later. Colleagues and peers remember him for his generosity, academic prowess, and significant contributions to historically informed music performance.

In the year ending March 2016, Scotland recorded 57 homicide cases (murders and culpable homicides), a decrease of five from the previous year and the lowest since 1976. Only one case from 2015-16 remained unresolved by March 31, 2016. The most common method of killing was with a sharp instrument, predominantly knives, accounting for 51% of cases. About 31% of the accused were under the influence of alcohol or both alcohol and drugs. Justice Secretary Michael Matheson emphasized the importance of continued efforts in education and enforcement to combat violent crime, highlighting the role of public services and law enforcement. Scottish Labour's justice spokeswoman Claire Baker noted the downward trend in homicides but cautioned about the reliability of statistics, citing past revisions, and pointed out a rise in sexual and violent crimes, including a 27% increase in attempted murder and serious assault. The homicide count for 2014-15 was initially 59 but was revised to 62 after reclassifications.

The Cherries lost 2-1 to Sunderland in a Premier League match, marking Sunderland's first win of the season in the league. Bournemouth took the lead with a goal from Dan Gosling, their first in three games, but were overtaken by goals from Sunderland's Victor Anichebe and a penalty by Jermain Defoe. Despite creating numerous chances and playing against 10 men after Steven Pienaar's dismissal, Bournemouth couldn't equalize. Manager Eddie Howe expressed frustration over the team's inability to convert chances into goals, despite their recent scoring record of six goals against Hull, emphasizing the importance of moving forward from this setback.

Mr. Abbott, speaking to Australian media, emphasized that the only way to prevent migrant deaths at sea is to "stop the boats," referencing Australia's policy of detaining migrants arriving by boat and processing them in offshore camps for resettlement elsewhere. This policy was criticized by the New York Times as "brutal," "inhumane," and of "dubious legality," contrasting with Australia's history of welcoming refugees. The newspaper also deemed it "unconscionable" for European leaders to adopt similar measures, as suggested by Mr. Abbott. Despite the criticism, Australia has not officially responded, though Mr. Abbott expressed sadness over the death of Syrian toddler Alan Kurdi and reiterated the necessity of stopping illegal boats to prevent such tragedies. Additionally, Mr. Abbott sparked controversy by comparing the Islamic State (IS) unfavorably to the Nazis, claiming IS openly boasts about their evil, unlike the Nazis who hid their actions. This statement drew criticism from the Executive Council of Australian Jewry, who found the comparison inappropriate, highlighting the systematic nature of Nazi genocide versus IS terrorism. Mr. Abbott stood by his remarks but clarified he was not ranking evils.

The United States has suspended bilateral talks with Russia due to intensified attacks by Russia and the Syrian government on civilians in Aleppo, Syria's largest city. This decision follows the collapse of a recent truce, after which Aleppo has faced heavy bombardment, including repeated strikes on a major trauma hospital in the rebel-held eastern part. Hundreds, including children, have died, and around 250,000 people are trapped in eastern Aleppo. The US accused Russia and the Syrian regime of targeting critical infrastructure and blocking humanitarian aid, citing a specific attack on an aid convoy. Russia denied involvement in the convoy attack and expressed regret over the US suspension of talks, accusing the US of failing to meet key conditions and shifting blame. Despite the suspension, both nations will continue discussions on counter-terrorism to prevent clashes.

The Policy Exchange report, supported by Downing Street, proposes selling high-value social housing when vacant to raise £4.5 billion annually, potentially funding the construction of 80,000 to 170,000 new social homes. This could be the largest social housing program since the 1970s and might reduce the 1.8 million social housing waiting list by about 500,000. The report identifies that 21.8% of UK social housing (816,000 properties) is "expensive," valued above regional averages, with a potential sale value of £159 billion. Neil O'Brien of Policy Exchange argues this would be fairer, allowing more families access to housing rather than a few living in high-value areas. The Prime Minister’s spokesman noted councils already have the option to sell high-value properties to optimize housing stock use. However, Labour and critics, including shadow housing minister Jack Dromey and Labour MP Karen Buck, oppose the plan, warning it could displace low-income families, disrupt mixed communities, and create segregated areas. They advocate for alternative funding like a bank bonus tax to build 250,000 affordable homes. Housing Minister Grant Shapps supports the sell-off and highlights government reforms, including a £19.5 billion investment to build up to 170,000 affordable homes and introduce fixed-term tenancies to prioritize those in greatest need.

Gareth Colfer-Williams, a 25-year-old from Swansea, died last week amidst a measles outbreak that has affected 942 people in the city since November, with 83 requiring hospital treatment. The cause of his death remains unclear as the initial examination could not confirm if measles was the primary factor; an inquest will be opened for further investigation. Mr. Colfer-Williams had recently been treated for asthma and developed a full-body rash shortly after being discharged from the hospital. He was found dead the morning after visiting an out-of-hours GP on April 17. Laboratory tests confirmed he had measles, but additional tests are needed to establish the cause of death. His family is unaware of how he contracted the disease, noting that no close family members, including his vaccinated three-year-old daughter, have it.

Vincent Hudson, a 54-year-old resident of Loweswater Avenue, Whitehaven, has been charged with a historical offence against a boy under 16, which reportedly occurred in 2001, according to Cumbria Police. He is scheduled to appear before North Cumbria Magistrates' Court.

In a National League match, Gateshead, under Neil Aspin and unbeaten in nine games, hosted Guiseley, managed by Adam Lockwood and unbeaten in five. Guiseley took the lead in the 15th minute with a goal by Jake Lawlor, despite Gateshead's dominance. Gateshead equalized in the 62nd minute through Wes York after a mistake by Guiseley's substitute Derek Asamoah. The game featured several substitutions and yellow cards, ending in a 1-1 draw. Match report provided by the Press Association.

Bristol Sport Ltd, the owner of a football club, plans to replace two stands to increase capacity at their current stadium, opting against building a new stadium at Ashton Vale due to delays caused by a town green application. Majority shareholder Steve Lansdown announced at a shareholder meeting that the redevelopment work, approved by Bristol City Council in November, will commence in May if no judicial review is requested by March. Lansdown also mentioned the imminent signing of the section 106 agreement, followed by a six-week judicial review waiting period.

Cuadrilla, a company conducting shale gas drilling or "fracking" in Lancashire, UK, has suspended operations following a 1.5 magnitude tremor, the second in two months, with the latest occurring near Poulton-le-Fylde. This follows a similar tremor on April 1. The company is analyzing data with the British Geological Survey (BGS) and consulting with authorities before deciding on future actions, a process expected to take weeks. Fracking, which involves breaking shale rocks to release gas, has been linked to small earthquakes due to the injection of pressurized water, as noted by the BGS. The process is controversial, with environmental concerns raised in the US about gas leaks into water supplies, though a UK Commons energy select committee supports fracking with strict regulations. The BGS continues to monitor the situation, confirming the recent quake's epicenter was within 2km of the drilling site at a depth of about 2km, similar to the previous event.

Angus Carpenter, a 62-year-old busker from Liverpool, was found guilty on one count of fraud for playing with a Hillsborough Justice Campaign banner on his bagpipes in April 2015, giving the impression he was collecting money for the charity. He was cleared of two other fraud charges at Liverpool Crown Court. Carpenter, who has performed in the city centre for over 30 years often wearing a kilt, claimed he was merely busking and not soliciting funds for the charity, despite having permission to display the banner as a tribute to the victims. The chairman of the Hillsborough Justice Campaign confirmed he had allowed the banner's design but not for fundraising purposes. Carpenter, a familiar figure at Anfield on match days, will be sentenced in January.

In a Championship match, Ipswich Town defeated Queens Park Rangers (QPR) 3-0. Grant Ward scored the opener with a scuffed shot, followed by Luke Varney capitalizing on a mistake by QPR goalkeeper Alex Smithies for the second goal. Tom Lawrence sealed the victory with a composed finish. Despite a late chance when QPR's Sandro hit the post, QPR struggled offensively and have only one win in their last six away games. Ipswich, who had struggled to score in recent matches, moved up to 14th in the standings, overtaking QPR who dropped to 15th. Ipswich manager Mick McCarthy praised his team's performance and highlighted the impact of Smithies' error, while QPR manager Ian Holloway expressed disappointment in his team's mental toughness and defensive errors.

Wells, a 23-year-old cricketer, had a notable performance in the T20 Blast last season, scoring 373 runs with an average of 28.69 and a strike rate of 138.66. He expressed enthusiasm about the positive direction of his club, highlighting the elite performance environment fostered by the coaches, which motivates the players to be involved.

The Reds, ranked fifth in National Two South, secured a second consecutive victory by defeating third-placed Chinnor 29-12. Coach Churcher praised the front row and front five, particularly Tommy Phillips, Ben Priddey, and Craig Williams, for their significant contribution with over 70 tackles in the game. Looking ahead, the Reds will play seven lower-ranked teams and the league leaders, Old Elthamians, in their next eight games. Churcher noted that while the win against Chinnor showed emotional resilience, it wasn't a complete performance, and emphasized the need to build on this result to ensure the effort wasn't wasted.

A 28-year-old man named Nazrul, also known as Nazu, allegedly a Bangladeshi citizen, was arrested at a Kolkata railway station for the rape of a 74-year-old nun in Ranaghat town on March 14. This arrest marks the sixth in the case, with two of the eight identified suspects still at large. The incident, which also involved theft and vandalism at a convent school, sparked widespread outrage and protests across India. Nazrul was identified as the primary perpetrator by the other five arrested suspects and was apprehended following a tip-off after returning from Bangladesh, where he had fled. Additionally, in May, Milon Sarkar was arrested and described as the gang leader, though his specific role remains unclear.

This passage describes an interactive video featuring Robert Opie, founder of the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising in London, discussing reasons behind changes in consumer buying habits in the UK, influenced by innovations like the domestic freezer, washing powder, and cheaper imports. The video, which may not function on older browsers, includes interactive elements on the ownership and ranking of major UK brands and is best viewed in full screen. A non-interactive version of the content is available, along with additional resources on topics like China's global ownership, food freezing tips, an annual survey of top UK consumer brands, and information about the Museum of Brands, Packaging and Advertising.

A 71-year-old woman from Sandyhills and another woman from Stranraer were deceived by scammers posing as BT technical support staff. The Sandyhills incident occurred on September 15, followed by the Stranraer incident on September 22. In the Stranraer case, the scammer gained remote access to the victim's computer and stole a substantial amount of money. PC Siobhan Pellett warned of the ease with which scammers access victims' computers and urged caution against cold calls requesting remote access or personal banking details, emphasizing that legitimate businesses never ask for such information over the phone.

Duffy, aged 37, has signed a one-year contract with Featherstone, a third-placed Championship side, after departing from Swinton Lions. He will coach Featherstone in their last league game against Toulouse and in the Super 8 Qualifiers. Chairman Mark Campbell praised Duffy's coaching abilities and his commendable work under tough conditions at Swinton. Duffy, with a 16-year playing career at Leigh, Widnes, and Salford, has been succeeded by his former assistant Stuart Littler at Swinton.

A Porthcawl RNLI crew, accompanied by a medic and a coastguard search and rescue helicopter, responded to an incident at Sker Beach near Kenfig Nature Reserve at 12:50 GMT on Sunday. The injured rider, who had head injuries and was very cold from lying unconscious on wet sand, was treated on-site and then airlifted to Cardiff's University Hospital of Wales for further care.

At a UN conference in Geneva, organized by the International Telecommunication Union (ITU), representatives from over 160 countries decided to allocate a specific radio frequency for a global flight tracking system. This decision, made at the World Radiocommunication Conference (WRC), aims to enhance the current system, which relies on ground-based radars and covers only about 30% of the world's airspace. The new system will use satellite tracking to receive automatic dependent surveillance-broadcast (ADS-B) signals from aircraft, enabling real-time tracking worldwide. This initiative was spurred by the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 in March 2014, which highlighted deficiencies in global air navigation systems. Debris from MH370, confirmed by Malaysian authorities, was found on Reunion Island. The ITU responded quickly to global demands for improved tracking, and the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) has set a deadline of November 2016 for new tracking guidelines, which will require aircraft to report their position at least every 15 minutes, or more frequently in emergencies.

Julian Hernandez, who disappeared at age five, has been found at 18 living with his father, Bobby Hernandez, in Cleveland. Bobby, 53, was arrested and is held at Cuyahoga County Jail in Ohio on a $250,000 bail, charged with tampering with records to obtain a driver's license in 2012. The FBI, tipped off on October 30 due to issues with Julian's college application, collaborated with Alabama police and the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to confirm his identity. Julian's mother has been informed of his recovery. Authorities had suspected Bobby in the disappearance since 2002, when he reportedly fled with Julian instead of taking him to pre-school.

A fire on 2 March at a Duncan Street site operated by Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited, managed by Asset and Land Group, led to several days of firefighter intervention, reduced train services, and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) suspended the company from accepting waste and revoked their environmental permit, effective 7 August unless appealed, requiring the company to remove all waste from the site. Despite being "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws as stated by Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS), concerns about potential impacts on residents, transport, and the environment were raised by GMFRS to the EA prior to the fire. The cause of the blaze remains undetermined.

The pro-Kremlin party A Just Russia has proposed two bills in response to the crisis in Ukraine's Crimea region, where separatist and pro-Russian sentiments are strong. The first bill would allow Russia to accept territories from disintegrating neighboring states if the territory's people or leaders express a desire to join Russia, bypassing the need for a treaty as required by current law. This change is motivated by the belief that existing laws are insufficient for crisis situations, as stated by Mikhail Yemelyanov, deputy leader of A Just Russia. The second bill aims to expedite the process of issuing Russian passports to Ukrainians, particularly Russian-speaking ones, by removing requirements like state tax, prior residence in Russia, financial self-sufficiency, and the need to renounce Ukrainian citizenship. This fast-track procedure, announced in Sevastopol by party leader Sergei Mironov, would allow citizenship applications at Russian diplomatic missions with a reduced waiting period of two months. The bills are linked to supporting Ukrainians amid the crisis, with a historical reference to fascist threats. Additionally, several Russian MPs and celebrities have visited Crimea, and there are historical precedents of Russia supporting pro-Russian separatists in Georgian territories like Abkhazia and South Ossetia since the 2008 war.

The passage discusses the historical success and current challenges of the McLaren Formula 1 team. Once a dominant force with 182 Grand Prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and 8 constructors' titles, McLaren has experienced a significant decline, particularly since 2013, due to issues with chassis design and now with the Honda power-unit. Despite having two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, the team struggles, currently aiming for modest grid positions and points. Historically, McLaren achieved great success with Honda in the late 1980s, dominating with drivers like Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost. The team faced scandals, such as the 2007 espionage issue with Ferrari and the 2009 'lie-gate', impacting their reputation. Founded by Bruce McLaren, the team saw early success in the 1970s but has cycled through periods of triumph and decline. Under Ron Dennis's leadership, McLaren saw periods of domination, but recent years have not yielded the desired turnaround. Despite this, Dennis and the team remain optimistic, believing that with improvements, particularly from Honda's engine next year, McLaren will challenge Mercedes' dominance and return to winning championships.

Thomas Baker, also known as Tommy, a 44-year-old from Everton, was fatally shot in the head and chest at Stanley Meat Market in Old Swan, Liverpool on January 27. He was attacked while getting into his car after leaving Phoenix Gym, and later died in hospital. Three Liverpool men, two aged 29 and one aged 32, have been arrested and are in custody for questioning. Merseyside Police are searching for a silver VW Polo seen leaving the scene quickly, and are urging people captured on CCTV near the market to come forward with potentially crucial information. Detectives believe the shooters had been waiting outside the gym for about an hour before the incident.

This passage discusses various ways to celebrate Christmas online while maintaining a spiritual focus. It highlights five key digital initiatives:

1. **Everyday Church Online**: Launched in the UK, this platform offers virtual Sunday services with streamed sermons and a chat room for global congregation interaction. Its Christmas theme, inspired by Star Wars, focuses on awakening hope for humanity with sermons titled "The Hope Awakens."

2. **Guardians of Ancora**: A free fantasy game for children aged 8-11, available on Android, iPhone, and Kindle. Developed by Scripture Union, it involves players as guardians rediscovering Bible stories to bring light to a darkened fictional world, with special Christmas content featuring quests about the birth of Jesus.

3. **Nativity Videos**: Two notable online videos retell the Christmas story. "The Digital Story of Nativity" by Viral.de uses social media formats like Facebook updates and tweets, amassing nearly six million views. The Churches Advertising Network's "Christmas Starts with a Baby's Giggle" portrays a modern couple transforming into Mary and Joseph, viewed about 250,000 times, though it faced rejection for cinema screening due to its religious content.

4. **Next Manga**: This company, after distributing millions of printed Manga-style Old Testament stories, has launched digital versions in app and e-book formats. Their nativity story, "Manga Messiah," is available in 33 languages, with copies sent to refugees in Syria and Libya to share a message of hope.

5. **Social Media Engagement**: Various Christian groups use platforms like Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to connect with communities, sharing brief spiritual messages to encourage reflection on higher values during Christmas.

These initiatives reflect a blend of technology and tradition to keep the spiritual essence of Christmas alive in a digital age.

The eight-day hearing in Ebbw Vale is reviewing a proposal to develop 250 hectares of common land, with Blaenau Gwent council and other supporters offering 320 hectares of replacement land. Expert opinions at the inquiry are divided: Natural Resources Wales finds it hard to confirm the replacement land's equal value but does not oppose the project, while an ecology report from the developers claims a biodiversity "net gain" due to nearby habitat enhancements—a claim disputed by the Gwent Wildlife Trust. The Planning Inspectorate for Wales will provide a recommendation post-inquiry, with the final decision resting with Welsh government ministers.

On 1 April, Novaya Gazeta reported that over 100 individuals suspected of being homosexual were detained in Chechnya, with at least three killed. The Russian LGBT Network confirmed the report, noting that detainees, including influential Muslim clerics and TV presenters, were tortured in a prison near Argun. Homophobia is prevalent in the predominantly Muslim North Caucasus republic, led by authoritarian Ramzan Kadyrov, who denies the allegations and claims there are no gay people in Chechnya. On 3 April, Chechen Muslim clerics condemned the report as an insult to their faith and dignity, issuing a resolution interpreted by Novaya Gazeta as a call for reprisals against journalists. The newspaper urged Russian authorities to prevent incitement of hatred towards journalists and affirmed its commitment to continue investigating human rights abuses in Chechnya. The LGBT Network is aiding victims to escape persecution and may pursue a case at the International Criminal Court if Russian authorities fail to act. Historical context includes the unresolved murders of Novaya Gazeta reporters and opposition politician Boris Nemtsov, linked to investigations of crimes in Chechnya.

Investing Solutions, a letting agency, and Fresh Start Housing, a charity, both based in the same south London storage unit, collaborate to house single homeless men, primarily over 35, in London. Founded by Samir Patel, Investing Solutions (2002) and Fresh Start Housing (2010) operate across seven London boroughs, with the former being one of the UK's largest recipients of housing benefit, making significant profits by charging housing benefit per tenant rather than per property. This results in higher benefit payouts compared to the rent passed to landlords, as seen in a case where they claimed £2,114 monthly for two tenants but paid the landlord £1,150, netting an annual gross profit of £11,568 on one property. Fresh Start refers clients from London homeless charities to both Investing Solutions and private landlords. Critics, including tenant Nigel McCann and homeless charity Crisis, have raised concerns about poor living conditions and exploitation, describing the partnership as "a new low." Despite operating legally, the arrangement has drawn scrutiny, with Wandsworth Council alone paying over £2.1m to Investing Solutions in two years. Both entities defend their practices, with Fresh Start housing 788 homeless individuals since its inception, and Patel asserting the independence of the charity and the majority of rents going to private landlords.

In a closely contested basketball game, Great Britain's team, coached by Joe Prunty, was led by London 2012 Olympian Andrew Lawrence with 14 points and NBA player Ben Gordon with 13 points. GB led for most of the first three quarters but was overtaken by the Netherlands in the final quarter, despite a late comeback attempt, resulting in a loss with the Dutch scoring the first 10 points of the fourth to lead 71-60. Worthy De Jong led the Netherlands with 18 points. This match was GB's final warm-up before roster cuts for their six-game Eurobasket qualifying campaign, starting with a game in Hungary. Coach Prunty emphasized the importance of intensity on both ends of the court for the qualifiers and praised Gordon's performance, especially in the third quarter where he scored three consecutive three-pointers.

The passage discusses the upcoming boxing match between Conor McGregor, a UFC lightweight champion making his boxing debut, and Floyd Mayweather, an undefeated boxer coming out of retirement. The fight, potentially the richest in history, is sanctioned by the Nevada Athletic Commission (NAC). A key issue is the glove weight for the 154 lbs bout; NAC rules mandate 10oz gloves, but Mayweather has expressed a desire to use 8oz gloves, which offer less hand protection but increase punch impact. Both fighters need to submit waivers for this change, with McGregor having submitted his just before the deadline. The NAC will debate this on August 16, prioritizing fighter safety. McGregor's background in UFC, where he used 4oz gloves, and his performance against Nate Diaz, whom he knocked down multiple times, were factors in approving the fight. Despite criticism from boxing figures, NAC executive director Bob Bennett supports the match, citing McGregor's skills and physical advantages over Mayweather, who hasn't knocked out an opponent in a decade. McGregor's camp has also hired experienced boxing referee Joe Cortez to adapt to boxing rules, following a controversial sparring session with Paulie Malignaggi.

The passage details the decline of Fleet Street in London, once the epicenter of British journalism, as exemplified by the closure of the Sunday Post's London office. Fleet Street, historically significant since the publication of the first British daily newspaper in 1702, was a hub for major national and provincial newspapers and a pinnacle for journalists’ careers. Reporters Gavin Sherriff and Darryl Smith, who worked for the Sunday Post for 32 and 25 years respectively, share personal anecdotes and memories of the street’s vibrant past, filled with bustling newsrooms, typewriters, and journalist-filled pubs. They recall the street’s transformation from a lively journalistic center to a quieter area with sandwich bars, reflecting broader changes in the industry. The narrative also includes insights from veteran journalists like Robin Esser and Liz Hodgkinson, who discuss Fleet Street’s critical role in public information before the rise of television and social media, and the gender dynamics and heavy drinking culture of the era. The passage notes the relocation of major newspapers to other parts of London starting in 1986, led by Rupert Murdoch, marking the end of Fleet Street’s dominance with the adoption of new technology and the repurposing of old newspaper buildings. Sherriff and Smith, now redundant, are moving on to freelancing and memoir writing, respectively, marking the end of an era as the last journalists depart from Fleet Street.

J.K. Rowling, the Harry Potter author, has faced significant online criticism on Twitter, particularly for her political views and donations. She donated £1m to the No campaign in the Scottish independence referendum and the same amount to the Labour Party in 2008. Recently, she was called a "traitor" for her views, leading her to block abusive users, some of whom she believed were Scottish National Party (SNP) supporters. Despite the negativity, Rowling noted the decency of most people and engaged positively with some SNP supporters, discussing shared political views. She also humorously responded to a suggestion of burning her books. Meanwhile, the SNP won 56 out of 59 seats in Scotland in the recent UK election, becoming the third largest party in the UK.

The passage discusses a study by University of Edinburgh researchers, published in Scottish Justice Matters, which reveals significant links between poverty and crime among young people in Scotland. Key findings include that children from deprived backgrounds are twice as likely to face police action for the same crimes as better-off children and are five times more likely to be placed on statutory supervision. Poverty increases the likelihood of violence in both genders, with boys being three times more likely to engage in violent acts than girls, and girls from poorer backgrounds twice as likely to be involved in violent crime compared to those from affluent households. The study, tracking 4,300 young people since 1998, also found that a history of police trouble strongly predicts a lack of education, employment, or training by age 18. Additionally, extreme poverty heightens the risk of being both a victim and perpetrator of crime. Despite a general decrease in crime rates in Scotland, areas with chronic crime issues, often the most deprived, have not seen benefits from this reduction. The Scottish government claims progress in safety and poverty alleviation, citing a 41-year low in recorded crime and significant investments to mitigate welfare cuts. However, researchers question the effectiveness of these measures in addressing inequality and the persistent concentration of crime in poor communities.

Mr. Karl Haugh, 25, was fatally stabbed in a laneway in the Marian estate, Kilkee, early Sunday morning. Robbie Walsh from Kilrush was charged with assault causing serious harm to Mr. Haugh and has been remanded in custody, with a court appearance scheduled for next week. Two other men arrested in connection with the incident were released without charge, and files are being prepared for the Director of Public Prosecutions. According to Det Sgt Padraig Frawley at Ennis District Court, Walsh and two others entered the estate around 01:00, looking for Haugh, leading to a fight involving weapons where Haugh was stabbed in the back. Knives and golf clubs were recovered at the scene by Garda, and Haugh was pronounced dead at Limerick University Hospital at 06:00. Evidence of local tension was noted, and Walsh's custody was extended until August 14.

In May 2014, Fermanagh MLA Phil Flanagan tweeted a defamatory statement about Tom Elliott, MP for Fermanagh and South Tyrone and former UDR member, questioning if Elliott would reveal alleged past harassments and shootings during a BBC radio programme. The tweet was deleted within an hour, and following legal action, Flanagan agreed to post an apology on Twitter acknowledging the falsehood of his statement. The High Court, presided by Mr Justice Stevens, heard that Elliott has a clear MoD record and was informed of the tweet by Ann Travers and Arlene Foster. Judgment on compensation is reserved, and Flanagan's insurance at Stormont has refused coverage for compensation and costs, a decision he is challenging separately. Elliott expressed satisfaction with the vindication, though disappointed by the 19-month duration to resolve the issue.

Hawick Knitwear, a company dating back to 1874 and employing over 230 staff, has increased its sweater production from 7,500 to 9,500 per week due to rising demand. This surge is attributed to strong sales of their newly launched Hawick Knitwear-branded range and growth in their established private label business. Acquired by managing director Benny Hartop in November of the previous year, the company sells to various European countries including Sweden, Finland, Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands, Belgium, France, Italy, and Spain, as well as non-European markets like the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Japan. Hartop credits the success to the dedicated staff and is optimistic about the company's future.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by a car driven by Brian Wright, 55, outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, who claims he was blinded by the setting sun, hit Mrs Blackburn while she was escorting a woman and child across the road at a red light. He denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs Blackburn is now in residential care. During the trial at Luton Crown Court, Wright expressed deep remorse for the incident and its impact on Mrs Blackburn and her family. The court noted the sun was near setting and could have affected Wright’s visibility. The trial is ongoing.

This passage describes a NATO anti-submarine warfare exercise named "Dynamic Mongoose," involving the German U-boat U33 acting as an enemy submarine attempting to target a command ship, USS Vicksburg, and an oil tanker. The exercise, involving 10 NATO warships, helicopters, a research vessel with underwater drones, and a French maritime patrol aircraft, aims to simulate the detection and tracking of submarines amidst growing concerns over Russian submarine activity. Rear Admiral Brad Williamson emphasizes the importance of this training due to increased Russian patrols near Sweden, Finland, and the UK. The text highlights the difficulty of locating submarines, likened to finding a needle in a haystack, and discusses technological aids like sonar, sensors, and underwater drones. It also points out a significant gap in Britain's defenses due to the absence of maritime patrol aircraft, making the UK reliant on NATO allies and vulnerable to Russian surveillance, especially near key naval bases. Russia's advanced submarine technology and growing military investment under President Putin are noted as major concerns, with their fleet of about 60 submarines described as highly sophisticated and challenging. The exercise underscores NATO's readiness for anti-submarine warfare while exposing vulnerabilities in some member nations' defenses, particularly Britain's.

The passage describes a severe humanitarian crisis in South Sudan, marked by potential genocide and ethnic cleansing as reported by United Nations officials. Since violence escalated in Juba in July and spread to the southern Equatoria states, 340,000 South Sudanese have fled to Uganda, surpassing the number of refugees from Syria in 2016. Daily, about 2,500 people become refugees, escaping ethnic-targeted killings, rapes, and violence primarily between the Dinka, Equatorians, and Nuer tribes. The conflict, rooted in a political dispute between Dinka President Salva Kiir and Nuer former Vice-President Riek Machar, intensified as it reached Equatorian regions. Personal accounts from refugees like Nelson Ladu Thomas and Otima Amos highlight brutal attacks and perilous escapes. Uganda, despite struggling with nearly a million refugees, manages the influx effectively with aid agencies, providing land and resources for shelters and farming. Bidi Bidi, once a village, is now one of the largest refugee settlements globally. Challenges remain, particularly with water supply, and there is a call for international intervention to halt the civilian massacres in South Sudan. Stories of loss and trauma are common among refugees, including children, as depicted through a poignant poem by a young girl named Patricia Mercy.

McKenzie, a 38-year-old former footballer turned professional boxer since 2013, will compete against Jahmaine Smyle for the English super-middleweight championship on November 12 at York Hall. With a record of eight wins and one draw in nine fights, McKenzie is the son of former British and European champion Clinton McKenzie and is trained by his uncle, Duke McKenzie, a former three-time world champion.

The Bridgwater Community Hospital project is funded by a £330m coalition investment for new NHS facilities in England, with a total project cost of £33m, the balance covered by NHS Somerset and Somerset Partnership NHS Foundation Trust. The new hospital will feature 30 inpatient beds, a midwifery-led maternity unit, a minor injury unit, X-ray facilities, and space for mobile scanners. The current hospital, built in 1813, is outdated, cramped, and in poor condition, as highlighted by Matron Sue Taylor, who notes the environmental impact on patient recovery. In recent years, three of Somerset's 13 community hospitals have been replaced, and construction has started on the Jubilee Building at Musgrove Park Hospital. Dr Donal Hynes, a local GP, emphasizes the positive impact on patient care and the collaborative healthcare delivery model. The new hospital is planned for Bowers Lane, pending planning permission, with a target completion date of autumn 2014.

A man was fatally shot outside a property on Daniel Hill Terrace in Upperthorpe, near the city centre, around 13:35 GMT. He was found with a gunshot wound to the chest near a black Mercedes he had been driving. Despite being rushed to Northern General Hospital, he succumbed to his injuries. The area was secured by armed police. Local residents noted that the victim was part of a nearby family and the shooting occurred during a family celebration, with relatives and neighbors attempting to assist after hearing the gunshot. This incident adds to a series of recent shootings in Sheffield, though previous ones occurred in the northern parts of the city, unlike this event in Upperthorpe. Recent incidents include a serious shooting in Shiregreen, shots fired through a window in Southey Green due to mistaken identity, and two separate shootings at houses in High Green.

The passage discusses the activities of three prominent hacker groups involved in the Ukraine-Russia conflict: the Ukrainian Cyber Troops, Cyber Berkut, and Anonymous International. The Ukrainian Cyber Troops, led by Yevhen Dokukin, are pro-Ukrainian hackers who have targeted Russian servers, rebel websites, and separatist funding through DDoS attacks and hacks into CCTV systems and network printers in eastern Ukraine and Crimea. They have provided data to Ukraine's security service and reportedly used hacked information for military purposes, though officials deny this. Cyber Berkut, an anti-Western group, opposes Ukraine's military actions, accusing Kiev of genocide under U.S. influence. They have hacked Ukrainian government websites, electronic billboards, and vote-counting systems, and leaked sensitive documents, including unverified claims about the downing of Malaysia Airlines flight MH17. Anonymous International, also known as Shaltay Boltay, focuses on Russian domestic affairs but has published materials related to Ukraine, including leaks suggesting local opposition to separatists in eastern Ukraine. Their website is currently blocked in Russia. These groups operate as independent activists, distinct from government-sponsored entities, and significantly impact the information and cyber warfare landscape of the conflict.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick was emotional during farewell speeches in the Scottish Parliament as several MSPs, including herself, Alex Salmond, and Duncan McNeil, announced their departure ahead of the May 5 election. Alex Salmond, former First Minister from 2007 to 2014, emphasized in his valedictory speech that Scotland is diverse rather than divided, and highlighted a consensus on the need for greater parliamentary responsibility. He acknowledged the transfer of powers under the Scotland Bill but criticized it for not meeting referendum campaign promises. Salmond also injected humor by referencing competing events like the UK budget and Cheltenham racecourse, and wished election candidates luck with varying enthusiasm. Duncan McNeil, a Labour MSP since 1999, warned in his final speech about the need for Holyrood to improve accountability and scrutiny, suggesting it learn from Westminster's committee system. Annabel Goldie, a former Scottish Conservative MSP, also retired, humorously noting she would miss her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney. Ms. Marwick thanked Salmond for his distinguished service to both the parliament and Scotland.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care across Wales. She is calling on pensioners, their families, and friends to share their experiences, which will inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira aims to highlight both exemplary care and the negative impacts of poor care, having observed significant variations in care quality firsthand. Her review will assess factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. While she emphasizes the importance of older people's voices, Mario Kreft of Care Forum Wales expressed disappointment over the lack of provider representation on the advisory panel, seeing it as a missed opportunity for partnership.

The Harbro Group, based in Aberdeenshire, reported an increase in pre-tax profit by £800,000 to £3.5m for the year ending June 2016, despite a £1m drop in turnover to just over £100m. The Turriff-based company, which manufactures and supplies feeds for various livestock sectors, saw growth in international sales in Europe and new markets. Harbro also operates 19 Country Store shops across Scotland, serving farming and rural communities with diverse products. The company acknowledges the unpredictable nature of the agricultural sector and the challenges faced in the past 12-18 months, as well as uncertainties due to Brexit, but remains confident in its positioning to handle future business challenges.

A man in his 70s was found dead at a house in Nettleden Road, Little Gaddesden, near Berkhamsted, on Saturday afternoon, and the death is being treated as murder. A man in his 80s was hospitalized following the incident. Police are seeking 55-year-old Ian John McLoughlin, also known as Ian John Baker, in connection with the crime and have warned the public not to approach him. McLoughlin is described as white, about 6ft tall, with greying, collar-length hair, average build, and was last seen wearing sunglasses, blue jeans or three-quarter length trousers, and a checked short-sleeved shirt. The investigation is in early stages, and police are conducting additional patrols in the area for public reassurance. Anyone with information is urged to contact the police or Crimestoppers.

David Lipton, the second in command at the IMF, spoke at the National Association for Business Economics in Washington, highlighting the weakening state of the global economy. He noted that the IMF's latest assessments indicate a delicate economic situation, exacerbated by a significant drop in China's exports, which fell by a quarter compared to the previous year. The IMF is likely to lower its global growth forecast from the current 3.4% in its upcoming April predictions. This downturn affects businesses and industries reliant on China's economic growth.

The passage discusses issues with a new chain ferry at Cowes, launched on 14 May, which has experienced multiple problems including breakdowns, grounding, and suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency due to training issues. Additionally, vehicles have been damaged during boarding and disembarking. In response, Council leader Dave Stewart announced that the crossing would be free until 2 July and a project review by auditors has been ordered, acknowledging the frustrating start. Local shopkeeper Angie Booth expressed concerns about the severe impact on local businesses due to loss of trade, questioning if compensation similar to that for damaged cars would be provided. Transport councillor Ian Ward noted that compensation is under discussion, described the ferry as a prototype with expected teething problems, and mentioned resolved electrical issues and the addition of ramp extensions to prevent vehicle damage. Grounding issues related to seamanship have also been addressed.

A fatal multi-vehicle crash occurred on the southbound carriageway near the Hindhead tunnel at Bramshott around 07:30 GMT on Thursday. A 32-year-old man died at the scene. A 33-year-old man from Waterlooville was arrested on suspicion of causing death by driving without due care and attention. The road between Thursley and Liphook was closed until early evening for police investigation.

Matching Models in London, an international temp agency, has faced criticism for its discriminatory job advertisements, including one for a personal assistant specifying physical attributes like "brown long hair with b-c cup" and another for a "sexy female driver." The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) and women's equality campaigners have condemned these ads as unlawful, demeaning, and outdated, with the EHRC planning to investigate the agency's hiring practices. Legal experts note that such ads violate the 2010 Equality Act by discriminating based on gender and potentially age, and could lead to unlimited compensation claims in employment tribunals. The agency's founder, Nathalie Jansen, defends the ads by emphasizing client preferences and the importance of appearance, citing specific client requests for particular looks. Matching Models serves high-profile clients like MTV and Louis Vuitton, and claims to prioritize first impressions while acknowledging the controversy over their hiring criteria.

A shooting incident took place at a hostel of the private Pragati Residential School in Bangalore, India, where Mahesh, an office assistant at the school, is alleged to have shot two students. He entered the room of 18-year-old Gautami, shooting her in the head, and also shot another student, Sirisha, who sustained severe injuries but is now out of danger. Mahesh was arrested after a manhunt on Wednesday and has been remanded until April 12. The motive behind the shooting remains unclear. Gun crimes at educational institutions in India are rare, despite the country having strict gun control laws, though firearms are often used to settle feuds.

The advocacy group Glaad's analysis of TV shows from June 2016 to May 2017 revealed 278 regular and recurring LGBT characters, with the number of transgender characters increasing from 7 to 16. However, they noted the concerning trend of over 25 lesbian and bisexual female characters being killed off, including Poussey Washington from "Orange is the New Black" and Bea Smith from "Wentworth." The report also highlighted a record high percentage of black characters on broadcast TV, largely due to shows like "Empire," "Luke Cage," and "How to Get Away with Murder." Glaad's study focused on scripted broadcast, cable, and streaming series, and while president Sarah Kate Ellis acknowledged progress, she emphasized that numbers are only part of the story.

David Mackintosh, the Conservative MP for Northampton South, has decided not to stand for re-election ahead of a local party meeting where his candidacy was likely to be opposed. This decision follows criticism over a £10.25 million loan from the borough council to Northampton Town Football Club for stadium redevelopment during his tenure as council leader. The money is now missing, prompting a police investigation into alleged financial irregularities, and the stadium remains half-built. Despite denying any wrongdoing, Mackintosh faced potential deselection by his party's local executive council. He expressed that it was a great honor to serve since 2015 but believes it is time for a new representative for his constituents.

Roy Oliver, a 37-year-old policeman, shot and killed 15-year-old Jordan Edwards by firing a rifle into a car driving away from a party in Balch Springs, a Dallas suburb, in April. The incident occurred after police responded to reports of underage drinking at a house party. Initially, police claimed the car reversed aggressively towards Oliver, but footage showed it driving forward, away from him. Oliver was fired days later for policy violations and charged with murder and four counts of aggravated assault with a deadly weapon against the other four teenagers in the car, including two of Edwards' brothers. He faces 5 to 99 years in prison for the murder charge and could be the first officer convicted of murder in Dallas County since 1973 if found guilty. Currently, he is out on bail, and no trial date has been set. The Dallas County DA, Faith Johnson, emphasized the pursuit of justice, while the Edwards family's lawyer, Lee Merritt, expressed cautious optimism, noting the rarity of such convictions in Texas. Jordan Edwards was highly regarded by his coach as an exemplary individual.

The president-elect announced that Melania Trump and their son Barron will relocate to Washington after Barron completes his school year, though no specific date was provided. This decision has sparked mixed reactions on social media, with some criticizing Melania for not immediately moving into the White House, a tradition upheld by most First Ladies, except for Martha Washington and Anna Harrison due to unique circumstances. Supporters argue that prioritizing Barron’s education is a responsible choice. Historically, other First Ladies like Frances Folsom Cleveland have also spent limited time in the White House for personal reasons, and it’s not uncommon for presidential children to finish school before moving. Melania has emphasized that Barron, age 10, is her primary focus, suggesting she may not take on the full traditional role of First Lady, which includes ceremonial duties and advocacy for causes. Past First Ladies like Michelle Obama and Eleanor Roosevelt embraced active public roles, while others, like Nancy Reagan, initially focused on personal support for their husbands. There is speculation about whether Ivanka Trump might assume some First Lady responsibilities, following historical precedents of family members stepping in. The passage also highlights how recent presidential families, including the Clintons and Obamas, balanced White House life with family normalcy, prioritizing privacy and family time.

A 72-year-old man was found dead in a sheltered housing complex in Inverness on 27 October this year. The Police Investigations and Review Commissioner (Pirc), Kate Frame, has been directed by the Crown Office and Procurator Fiscal Service (COPFS) to investigate the initial police response to the man's call. Police Scotland is fully cooperating with the investigation, and a report on the findings will be submitted to the COPFS.

A yellow warning of wind has been issued, with gusts up to 75mph (120kmph) expected, especially west of the mountains, and the unusual easterly wind direction may worsen the impact. Travel disruptions on roads and at sea are anticipated in the Welsh counties of Conwy, Anglesey, Gwynedd, Pembrokeshire, Carmarthenshire, Ceredigion, and Powys. Overnight gusts caused a tree to fall in Menai Bridge on Anglesey, leading to the closure of Telford Road for most of Monday for cleanup.

In the hockey match, the Giants took an early lead with a goal from player-coach Derrick Walser, but Jeff Dimmen equalized for the Panthers. In the second period, Mike Forney scored on a powerplay breakaway to make it 2-1 for the Giants, followed by Andy Bohmback tying the game. Mike Radja then scored from a sharp angle, and James Desmarais extended the Giants' lead to 4-2, before David Ling scored for Nottingham, narrowing the gap. The teams will play again on Saturday night in the second game of their double-header. Nottingham currently leads the league with 28 points, followed by Sheffield Steelers with 27 and Belfast with 25.

In a chaotic Chinese Grand Prix, world champion Lewis Hamilton started from the back, endured a broken front wing on the first lap, made five pit stops, and finished behind Ferrari's Kimi Raikkonen, who overtook him late in the race. Hamilton now faces a 36-point deficit to leader Nico Rosberg with 18 races left, a challenging gap as no driver winning the first three races has ever failed to win the championship. Rosberg won the race comfortably after early incidents, including a collision between Ferrari teammates Sebastian Vettel and Raikkonen, and a risky move by Red Bull's Daniil Kvyat, which led to a heated exchange with Vettel despite both finishing on the podium (Vettel second, Kvyat third). Multiple first-lap collisions, including one involving Hamilton and Sauber's Felipe Nasr, caused significant car damage and necessitated early pit stops under a safety car. Hamilton's car suffered aerodynamic and suspension damage, hindering his recovery, while Rosberg's strategic decisions and clear lead secured his victory.

Thomas Hitzlsperger, a prominent German footballer, publicly revealed his homosexuality in an interview with Die Zeit, aiming to advance the discussion on a topic often ignored in German football. His announcement received widespread support from teammates like Lukas Podolski and Arne Friedrich, as well as from figures in German football administration, including Theo Zwanziger and Reinhard Rauball, who praised his courage. Hitzlsperger, the first player from the Premier League to come out, was also commended by Bayern Munich, his initial club, and public figures like Gary Lineker and Joseph Barton. His action is seen as a significant step against homophobia in football, a persistent issue in Germany and England. Despite past discouragement from figures like Philipp Lahm and ongoing challenges in openly discussing homosexuality in football, there is optimism from Zwanziger and others, including German Chancellor Angela Merkel's spokesman Steffen Seibert and politician Volker Beck, that Hitzlsperger's bravery will encourage greater openness and acceptance in the sport.

Sidwell, a 34-year-old midfielder, has played 32 Championship games this season for Brighton, also known as the Seagulls, aiding their promotion to the Premier League for the first time in 34 years. With his contract expiring at season's end, Sidwell is keen to sign a new deal, confident in the team's ability to remain in the top flight. Brighton's promotion was secured with a recent victory over Wigan, and they hold a four-point lead over Newcastle, aiming to clinch the league title in their last two games. Sidwell, who joined Brighton on a one-year contract in June 2016 after a loan from Stoke, has prior Premier League experience with several clubs and believes his performances, exceeding expectations with significant impact, merit a contract extension. He hopes to finalize a new deal to continue with Brighton next season.

In a match between Blackpool and Colchester United that ended in a 1-1 draw, Blackpool scored first through Jamille Matt after 12 minutes, following a precise chip from Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized shortly after from a corner, with Kurtis Guthrie scoring in a goalmouth scramble. Both teams had chances to take the lead, with notable saves by Blackpool's goalkeeper Sam Slocombe, including a sensational denial of Matthew Briggs and a close-range save from George Elokobi. Blackpool missed a potential winning goal when Tom Aldred headed wide from a corner. The game concluded with Colchester reduced to 10 men after Sean Murray received a straight red card for a bad tackle in injury time. Several players from both teams received yellow cards for fouls during the match.

The 29-year-old player, Reid, who played 37 games for the Sky Blues last season during their relegation from League One, has previously been with Charlton, Bradford, and Preston. He might debut for Colchester United (the U's) in an EFL Cup first-round match against Aston Villa on Wednesday. Colchester began their season with a 3-1 loss to Accrington.

The murder of PC Keith Palmer outside the Houses of Parliament in March has intensified the push for a permanent UK Police Memorial at the National Memorial Arboretum in Alrewas, Staffordshire. The UK Police Memorial Trust is seeking £1.5m for the project, which will honor over 1,400 fallen officers and staff from the past 250 years. The memorial will feature a brass screen with leaf shapes cut out as personal memorials for families, bearing the names of the deceased. Sir Hugh Orde, chairman of the trust, emphasized the importance of a national site for remembrance and recognition of police sacrifices. The government, through Home Secretary Amber Rudd, has pledged £1m towards the £4m total cost, with completion expected by 2019.
