Chief Inspector Paul Wilson emphasized the need for urgent improvements in management and enforcement of court sentences. The Ministry of Justice acknowledged the issues, accepted the recommendations, and is taking action to ensure offenders attend and face consequences for non-compliance.

The passage discusses a controversy surrounding a comedian, referred to as Brand, who is accused of hypocrisy by a newspaper for advocating economic and political revolution to aid the poor while living in a luxurious London home. This accusation is not new, and Brand has faced similar criticism before. During a protest outside the Prime Minister's residence in support of east London estate residents facing displacement, a reporter questioned Brand about his own high rent and the issue of the super-rich buying property in London, to which Brand reacted negatively, calling the journalist a "snide" and walking away. Brand has not confirmed whether he will take legal action against the newspaper, The Sun, or its owner, Rupert Murdoch, though he has tweeted about the accusations using the hashtag #TheSunLogic. In past statements, Brand acknowledges the hypocrisy charge, admits to personal flaws and the need for personal change, and insists that systemic change is necessary to address economic disparity and ecological issues, despite his personal wealth and past mistakes.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, significantly accelerated the mapping of the human genome by turning it into a competitive race, though this approach drew criticism from the scientific community. Despite being vilified for his lack of modesty and disregard for scientific conventions like open data access, Venter's efforts culminated in the publication of the human genome in 2001 alongside a public project. He founded Celera Genomics in 1998 to decode the human genetic code in just three years, a goal achieved concurrently with the public effort. Post-genome, Venter focused on creating a synthetic life form, resulting in an organism named Synthia, developed at the J Craig Venter Institute and published in Science. Born in 1946, Venter's early life was unremarkable academically; however, his experiences as a medical orderly in Vietnam during the Tet offensive instilled a sense of urgency and a drive to become a doctor. His career shifted towards research in molecular biology at the US National Institute of Health, where he pioneered faster gene sequencing techniques. After facing funding challenges and criticism, he established The Institute for Genomic Research in 1992 and later unveiled the first complete genome of a free-living organism in 1995. Financially successful, Venter has pursued independent research, including a marine genetic project aboard his yacht, Sorcerer II, and continues to innovate with synthetic microbes, aiming to revolutionize industry and address environmental issues.

A survey of about 1,000 parents in England, commissioned by England's School Food Trust, revealed that four out of five children who ate school lunches tried new foods at school that they hadn't eaten at home, with half of the parents noting their children requested these foods at home. Carrots, sweetcorn, and peas were the most popular vegetables, while aubergine, chickpeas, and spinach were among the least favored. The research, prompted by a Mumsnet survey indicating parental concerns over children's fussiness, showed that school meals help encourage children to try diverse foods. Rob Rees of the School Food Trust and Carrie Longton of Mumsnet highlighted the positive influence of school meals and peer pressure in promoting varied diets. Currently, school meals in England adhere to strict nutritional guidelines, with about 40% of primary school children and slightly fewer secondary school children eating them, compared to 46% in Scotland. The survey was conducted online from February 26 to March 5 among parents of school-aged children (4-17 years).

Alvaro Morata, a 23-year-old Spanish striker, joined Juventus from Real Madrid in 2014 with a buy-back option for Real, potentially up to 30 million euros. During his two years at Juventus, he scored 27 goals and won two Serie A titles and two Coppa Italias. Morata has also played in consecutive Champions League finals, including Real's 2014 victory and Juventus' 2015 loss to Barcelona. Currently playing for Spain at Euro 2016, he has scored three goals in the tournament. Previously, he came through Real Madrid's youth system, debuting for the first team at 18 and scoring 10 goals for them. Reports have linked him with moves to Arsenal and Chelsea.

Wilson, a 30-year-old footballer, returned to Championship side Forest from Celtic for £2.5m in August 2013. He has been without a team since his release in May. During his second stint at Forest, he made 51 appearances. Previously, he played four seasons at Forest before moving to Celtic and has also played for Preston North End and Notts County.

Tesco, the world's third largest retailer, is exiting the US market by transferring its loss-making Fresh & Easy chain to Yucaipa, a Los Angeles-based private equity firm led by billionaire Ron Burkle. Approximately 4,000 of Fresh & Easy's 5,000 employees will move to the new business. Tesco will loan the new entity about £80m and incur a cost of £150m to dispose of the brand, though part of this may be repaid. Fresh & Easy, with 200 stores in California, Nevada, and Arizona, has been unprofitable since 2007. Of these, 150 stores are being transferred, while the remaining 50 will close. Tesco retains an option to buy a stake in the business if it becomes profitable under Yucaipa. This move follows Tesco's first annual profit decline in 20 years, reported in April.

The passage discusses an individual who faced racial abuse but managed to overcome it. He considered representing France before deciding to aim for a medal at the 2016 Rio Olympics. Additionally, the passage directs readers to a special guide on getting into martial arts.

In the late 1960s/early 1970s, the ice fields in the French Alps, including Mont Blanc and surrounding massifs, covered approximately 375 sq km, which decreased to about 275 sq km by the late 2000s, marking a 26% loss over 40 years. This data, presented at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting, was compiled by Marie Gardent and her team from the University of Savoie using map archives, satellite imagery, and aerial photographs, with manual checks to ensure accuracy. The retreat of glaciers is more pronounced in the southern sectors of the French Alps, such as the Belledonne and Ecrins Massifs, compared to the northern areas like the Mont Blanc Massif, due to lower elevations and differing climatic conditions including less precipitation and cloud cover in the south. The largest French glacier, La Mer de Glace, has also slightly decreased in size over the same period. Similar trends of accelerating glacier retreat are observed across other parts of the Alps in neighboring countries.

The Scottish women's national football team, having won all five of their qualifiers, is set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday. A victory would nearly secure their spot in the finals. Ranked just below Iceland at world number 21, Scotland faces a strong opponent who is also unbeaten with four wins. The matches against Iceland, including a return fixture in Reykjavik on September 20, are crucial for determining the group leader. With the top six runners-up also qualifying automatically for next summer's finals in the Netherlands, Scotland is well-positioned to avoid a play-off. Forward Lisa Evans, a 24-year-old Bayern Munich player, emphasizes the team's determination to reach the finals, a goal shared by veteran goalkeeper Gemma Fay for 15 years. Evans highlights the importance of fan support and the competitive advantage gained from Scottish players, including herself, playing in top international leagues like Germany’s Bundesliga. She also reflects on her recent Bundesliga win with Bayern Munich and the enriching experience of playing abroad, which she believes strengthens the national team.

Stuart Campbell, a blogger and Scottish independence campaigner who runs the Wings Over Scotland blog, was arrested in the west of England on Friday after a woman in south London accused him of online harassment over a two-year period. Campbell, who was released on bail until mid-September, stated that the allegations relate to non-threatening tweets from his account, which remain publicly visible. He criticized the media for encouraging speculation through innuendo. The Metropolitan Police confirmed they are investigating the harassment claim. Campbell announced on Twitter he would post less frequently due to circumstances beyond his control.

People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (Peta) proposes replacing the traditional Jolly Fisherman mascot of Skegness with a fish mascot and the slogan "Skegness - A Happy Plaice," arguing that the current mascot represents cruelty to animals by depicting fish suffering. The original Jolly Fisherman poster, created in 1908 for the Great Northern Railway with the slogan "Skegness is so bracing," is an iconic symbol of the Lincolnshire resort. Peta believes their suggestion offers a chance to rebrand Skegness as a progressive, animal-friendly destination. However, Skegness mayor Carl Macey defends the mascot, stating it is beloved and does not portray animal cruelty, but rather a happy and friendly image. He acknowledges Peta's suggestion will be considered by the council, though he doubts there will be significant support to replace Jolly.

In a rugby match, Scotland decisively defeated Georgia despite an early try by Georgia's Vasil Lobzhanidze. Scotland quickly took the lead with tries from Tommy Seymour, a penalty try, Sean Maitland, and Stuart Hogg before halftime, followed by Hamish Watson's try after the break. Lobzhanidze scored a second try for Georgia from a strong scrum, but Hogg added another try for Scotland with a brilliant counter-attack, securing a final score of 43-16. Scotland dominated possession and territory, with notable contributions from Greig Laidlaw's conversions. Georgia struggled but managed two penalties and showed strength in the scrum, causing issues for Scotland, including a yellow card for Moray Low. Scotland's head coach Vern Cotter praised the team's first-half performance and their ability to manage the game, despite a less precise second half due to wet conditions.

In the rugby match, Widnes secured a 38-12 victory over Castleford, despite a late comeback attempt by the Tigers. Widnes took a 14-6 lead at halftime with tries from Macgraff Leuluai, Ah Van, and Chris Bridge, while Paddy Flynn scored for Castleford. In the second half, Flynn added two more tries, completing a hat-trick, but Widnes extended their lead with additional tries from Ah Van, Lloyd White (2), and Joe Mellor. Castleford fought back with quick tries from Larne Patrick, Luke Gale, and Flynn, narrowing the gap and making the finish tense. However, Widnes held firm, ending a streak of nine losses in their last ten games. This win moved Widnes to seventh place, just one point behind Castleford, who remain in sixth after suffering their fourth consecutive home league defeat.

Fawzi al-Odah, a 37-year-old Kuwaiti, was released from the US detention facility at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, after being held since 2002 on suspicion of links to al-Qaeda and the Taliban, charges he denies. A US review panel concluded he was no longer a "continuing significant threat," leading to his release, which was facilitated by a Kuwaiti government plane. Despite his release, he must spend at least a year in a militant rehabilitation center in Kuwait. His lawyer expressed joy and no bitterness about the release. This is the first release since May, reducing the number of inmates at Guantanamo to 148. The facility, opened in 2002 after the 9/11 attacks, remains a point of contention, with President Obama promising to close it.

Thousands attended an early morning service at Hyde Park Corner and a parade of up to 400 people before a wreath-laying at the Cenotaph to commemorate Anzac Day, which marks the first major battle of Australian and New Zealand forces in World War One. Additional services were held at Westminster Abbey, where the national anthems of New Zealand and Australia were sung. Anzac Day, first commemorated in London in 1916 by King George V, remembers the Anzac landings at Gallipoli and honors the sacrifices of Australians and New Zealanders in all wars. Australian High Commissioner Alexander Downer spoke at the dawn service about the courage and heroism of the Anzac troops during the Gallipoli landings. The ceremony also included veterans, service personnel, their families, and featured prayers by schoolchildren and the national anthems of Australia, New Zealand, and the UK. The Gallipoli campaign, a significant and bloody eight-month operation, aimed to force the Ottoman Empire out of the war.

David Clarkson, aged 30, has rejoined Premiership Well and is set to possibly debut for St Mirren in the Championship against Alloa on Saturday. Having scored nine goals for Dundee last season, Clarkson has mostly played as a substitute this term but asserts his readiness and fitness for matches, having also played with the U20s. With nearly 400 senior club appearances and two caps for Scotland in 2008, where he scored one international goal, Clarkson has previously played for Bristol City, Brentford, and Bristol Rovers. St Mirren, currently eighth in the Championship, are seven points ahead of last-placed Alloa. Clarkson is eager to contribute to winning games to boost team confidence and improve their standing in the league table.

The turkey company Bernard Matthews was acquired by food tycoon Ranjit Boparan on Tuesday. Despite initial concerns, the new ownership, through Boparan Private Office, has assured that all current pension agreements will be honored, including an alternative pension scheme unaffected by the takeover since the final salary scheme closed in 2004. Unite regional officer Steve Harley confirmed productive discussions with Boparan's representatives at the Great Witchingham headquarters, where it was stated that Boparan aims to return Bernard Matthews to high profitability through increased investment, cost savings, and expanding production to include chicken alongside turkeys.

At a council scrutiny meeting, Council leader Dave Stewart announced that the Cowes crossing would be free until July 2 due to ongoing issues with the new chain ferry, which launched on May 14. The ferry has experienced multiple problems including breakdowns, grounding, and a suspension by the Maritime and Coastguard Agency over training issues. Additionally, vehicles have been damaged during boarding and disembarking. Stewart also mentioned a council-ordered audit review of the project, describing the ferry's start as "frustrating and disappointing." Local shopkeeper Angie Booth expressed concerns about the severe impact on local businesses due to loss of trade, questioning if compensation would be provided similar to that for damaged cars. Transport councillor Ian Ward noted that compensation is under discussion and described the ferry as a prototype with expected teething problems, mentioning resolved electrical issues and the addition of ramp extensions to prevent vehicle damage. He also stated that grounding issues related to seamanship have been addressed.

The passage discusses the implications of Brexit on the UK fishing industry. It highlights a House of Lords report which warns that despite the industry's small economic contribution (0.5% of GDP and employing 12,000 fishers), it must not be sidelined in Brexit negotiations. Many in the fishing community see Brexit as a chance to regain control over UK waters and boost fish exports, similar to Norway. However, the report notes potential trade-offs, such as granting EU boats access to UK waters to maintain tariff-free access to the European market, where most UK fish are exported. The report also suggests retaining elements of the EU's Common Fisheries Policy, like scientifically-based quotas, and warns of fragmented fisheries management across England, Wales, Northern Ireland, and Scotland post-Brexit. Despite these concerns, recent EU quota increases for certain fish species and optimism from industry leaders like Bertie Armstrong of the Scottish Fishermen's Federation suggest a positive outlook for British fishing outside the EU, with hopes for fairer shares and sustainable management. The government aims to balance trade freedoms with sustainable fisheries management during EU negotiations.

Timothy Geaney admitted to taking or permitting images of young boys in erotic poses to be taken between April 2004 and February 2014. He was subjected to a community payback order, placed on the sex offenders register, and ordered to participate in a special program for sex offenders. Following a General Teaching Council Scotland hearing, Geaney was removed from the teaching profession's register due to conduct deemed incompatible with being a registered teacher. The panel noted the long duration and volume of images involved, indicating a pattern of behavior rather than an isolated incident, and concluded there was a strong likelihood of recurrence due to lack of remedial action. Geaney, aged 69 at sentencing, was not present at the hearing and is prohibited from re-applying for registration for two years.

A fire on 2 March at a site on Duncan Street, managed by Recovered Fuels Shipping Limited under Asset and Land Group, led to several days of firefighter intervention, reduced train services, and travel delays. The Environment Agency (EA) revoked the company's environmental permit, effective 7 August unless appealed, prohibiting future operations at the site and mandating waste removal. Despite being "broadly compliant" with fire safety laws as per Greater Manchester Fire and Rescue Service (GMFRS), which visited the site nine times in the past year, concerns about potential fire impacts on residents, transport, and the environment were raised to the EA in February, leading to joint inspections and subsequent enforcement action. The cause of the fire is still undetermined, and the company could not be reached for comment.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad stated that Syria is striving to meet the deadline for destroying its chemical weapons, despite missing a recent deadline to surrender its entire stockpile of about 1,300 tonnes. Only 4% (30 tonnes) has been removed from the country so far. Mekdad reported that shipments faced attacks by terrorist groups en route to the port of Latakia. He defended Syria's actions amidst war conditions and criticized US Secretary of State John Kerry's remarks on the use of barrel bombs in Aleppo, where significant civilian casualties have been reported. Meanwhile, conflicting reports emerged about a rebel assault on Aleppo's central prison, with claims of rebels freeing detainees contrasted by state media denials. The US and Russia have expressed concerns over delays in the chemical weapons removal, with a target completion date set for the end of June under the supervision of the Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons (OPCW), which acknowledges security issues as a hindrance. Mekdad reaffirmed Syria's commitment to its international obligations.

England secured a commanding victory over Pakistan at Old Trafford, leveling the series with a day to spare. They declared at 589-8 and 173-1, achieving their second largest win by runs against Pakistan. Joe Root, named man of the match, excelled with 254 in the first innings and an unbeaten 71 in the second, also contributing with four catches and a wicket. Captain Alastair Cook praised Root's performance at number three, while coach Trevor Bayliss noted Root's dedication after a previous defeat. Pakistan struggled, batting only 63 and 70 overs in their innings, scoring 198 and 234 respectively, with their spirit described as broken by Geoffrey Boycott. Pakistan's captain Misbah-ul-Haq expressed disappointment over poor shot selection and lack of confidence, though he remains hopeful for a comeback. The series, expected to be tight per Michael Vaughan, continues with the third Test at Edgbaston on August 3, following Pakistan's tour game against Worcestershire.

Sarah Rochira, the Older People's Commissioner for Wales, is conducting a review into the quality of life and care of older people in residential care across Wales. She is calling on pensioners, their families, and friends to share their experiences, which will inform recommendations for care providers and public bodies. Rochira aims to highlight both exemplary and poor care practices, having observed significant variations in care quality firsthand and through increased correspondence over the past year. The review will assess factors like physical and psychological health, social relationships, and the care home environment. While Care Forum Wales supports the review's goals, they express disappointment over the lack of provider representation on the advisory panel, feeling it misses a chance for full sector engagement and partnership.

Paul Sheerin, a 39-year-old former Dons midfielder, has been appointed as the new player-manager at Pittodrie, replacing Neil Cooper. Sheerin has been with Arbroath since 2010, but the team was relegated to Scottish League Two after finishing last in League One in the 2013-14 season. Aberdeen's chief executive, Duncan Fraser, noted that Sheerin was selected by boss Derek McInnes after a thorough process, and despite Arbroath's wish to keep him, their chairman John Christison supported Sheerin's move back to Aberdeen. Sheerin, who played for various Scottish clubs and Östersunds in Sweden, also earned a Scotland Under-21 cap in the mid-1990s. During his tenure at Arbroath, he led the team to their first national trophy by winning the Scottish Third Division title and securing promotion in 2011.

Curtis and assistant manager Paul Williams will manage Swansea's upcoming match against Bournemouth following the dismissal of Bob Bradley. The club is eager to quickly appoint a new manager, with Paul Clement as the top candidate. Swansea, promoted to the Premier League in 2011, has a history of financial struggles and a near relegation in 2003, but rose to prominence with a reputation for exciting, possession-based football under managers like Roberto Martinez, Brendan Rodgers, and Michael Laudrup. Curtis, a former player, believes the team has lost its identity, the 'Swansea Way', since Laudrup's departure in 2014 due to frequent managerial changes and inadequate player replacements. He remains optimistic about the current squad's ability to avoid relegation, emphasizing the importance of staying in the Premier League for the club and the local area, and notes the difficulty of returning to the top flight if relegated, citing the strengthened competition in the Championship.

Dr. Craig Venter, a biologist and entrepreneur, significantly accelerated the mapping of the human genome by turning it into a competitive race, though this approach drew criticism from the scientific community. Despite his lack of modesty and controversial methods, his work in genomics has been impactful. After the human genome project, Venter focused on creating a synthetic life form, resulting in an organism named Synthia, developed at the J Craig Venter Institute and published in Science. Born in 1946, Venter's early life was unremarkable academically; he was drawn to surfing before being drafted into the Vietnam War in 1967, an experience that instilled a sense of urgency and led him to pursue a medical career. Excelling in research, he pioneered faster gene sequencing techniques at the US National Institute of Health and later founded The Institute for Genomic Research after facing funding issues. In 1995, he sequenced the genome of Haemophilus influenzae, and in 1998, he launched Celera Genomics to decode the human genome swiftly, achieving results by 2001 alongside a public project. Financially successful, Venter has funded his own research, including oceanic genome sequencing expeditions and the development of synthetic microbes, which he believes could revolutionize industry and environmental conservation. His career, marked by innovation and controversy, reflects his drive to push scientific boundaries.

The Sutton Trust, supported by a study from the Boston Consulting Group, criticizes the quality and duration of many apprenticeships in England, noting that only about 200,000 of the 520,000 annual apprenticeship starts are at level three (equivalent to A-level), and over half since 2010 are below this level. Compared to Germany, where over half of employers offer apprenticeships and 90% are at A-level equivalent, only 20% of English employers provide such opportunities, and just 61,000 new starts are for young people. The report highlights a complex vocational system in England with 18,000 qualifications, contrasting with Germany's 330, and notes intense competition with 11 young people per apprenticeship. It calls for an expansion to 300,000 new starts annually, mostly at level three or higher, lasting at least three years. Sir Peter Lampl of the Sutton Trust emphasizes the importance of quality apprenticeships for social mobility and economic competitiveness. The Department for Education claims ongoing reforms to improve apprenticeship standards, including a minimum duration of one year and integration of more English and maths. The Association of Colleges acknowledges the challenge of expanding apprenticeships and supports preserving some respected level two programs, while agreeing on the need for high-quality facilities and better career guidance.

Sarah Storey, Britain's most decorated female Paralympian, won a cycling event in Nottwil, Switzerland, finishing over two minutes ahead of Poland's Anna Harkowska. This victory marks her 21st world title across cycling and swimming. The 37-year-old, who has earned 22 Paralympic medals including 11 golds, is aiming for further success at the 2016 Rio Paralympics. Storey, who started in swimming and won six medals at the 1992 Paralympics, switched to cycling in 2005. She has the opportunity to claim a 17th title in an upcoming road race on Saturday.

Hereford United, also known as the Bulls, have been expelled from the Football Conference due to unresolved financial difficulties, with debts amounting to approximately £225,000, including £148,000 owed to football creditors. Despite multiple deadline extensions by the Conference to settle these debts, the club, recently taken over by London businessman Tommy Agombar, failed to meet the final deadline on June 12. Chester FC has been reinstated in the Conference Premier, taking Hereford's place after a dramatic final day of the season where Hereford initially stayed up. The Hereford United Supporters' Trust offered to buy the club for £1 and clear its debts, but this was not accepted. The club's financial decline has been worsened by falling attendance, dropping from an average of 3,270 in League Two to 1,758 in the 2013-14 season. This expulsion marks a sad day for supporters and players, whose efforts to keep the club in the league have ultimately been in vain.

James Milner, a former Manchester City player, earned 61 caps for England since his debut in 2009. He participated in two World Cups and two European Championships, though he only played three minutes at Euro 2016. Milner, who also holds the record for the most caps at the England Under-21 level with 46, scored his sole international goal during a 5-0 win against Moldova in the 2014 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. He recently made a decision, described as common sense, and wished success to Sam Allardyce, the team, staff, and supporters.

Christopher Hogwood, a pivotal figure in the early-music movement, passed away at his home in Cambridge after a prolonged illness. He founded the Academy of Ancient Music (AAM) in 1973, leading it for 30 years across six continents and producing over 200 CDs, including a notable complete cycle of Mozart symphonies on period instruments and a highly acclaimed 1980 recording of Handel's Messiah. Hogwood, who studied keyboard at Cambridge University, held various prestigious positions, including artistic director roles at the King's Lynn Festival and Boston's Handel and Haydn Society, and academic roles at Harvard, Cambridge, and Cornell Universities. His funeral will be private, with a memorial service planned for later. Colleagues and peers remember him for his generosity, academic prowess, and significant contributions to historically informed music performance.

A boy from Northern Ireland, whose identity is protected, has been removed from mainstream schooling due to coping difficulties, prompting his mother to quit her job to care for him. Since June, his family has been awaiting a placement in a special school, but all schools in the South Eastern Education Board area are at full capacity with no clear timeline for availability. The boy's mother expressed to BBC's Good Morning Ulster that her son feels isolated and misses social interaction. Recently, the family learned of an additional classroom assistant at a local special school, with hopes of a placement soon. However, concerns remain about the overcrowded special needs school system affecting other families. The Education Authority declined to comment on this specific case due to privacy concerns but noted an ongoing review of special school places in Northern Ireland, aiming to ensure local availability starting from 2016.

The passage discusses the potential takeover of Newport Gwent Dragons by the Welsh Rugby Union (WRU), who view Rodney Parade primarily as a rugby venue. Newport County, a fellow tenant at Rodney Parade, holds a lease until 2023 with fixture primacy if they stay in the Football League. County's chairman, Foxall, insists on the contract being honored. A shareholder vote on the WRU's takeover is scheduled for May 9. Newport RFC chairman Will Godfrey confirms that both County and Newport Squash Club are protected under existing agreements, a fact acknowledged by the WRU. However, the WRU plans to install an artificial surface, which violates Football League rules. On the field, Newport County is close to securing survival in League Two, being two points clear of relegation with two games left under caretaker manager Mike Flynn. Relegation would be a significant setback for the club and the city, according to Foxall.

The passage recounts the personal journey of a man from Sierra Leone who was kidnapped at 15 by the Revolutionary United Front (RUF) during the civil war that began in 1991. Forced into violence and drug use, he eventually escaped and struggled in Freetown until meeting Richard Cole, a preacher who helped him through the Lifeline Nehemiah project, encouraging him to rebuild his life and contribute to society. Inspired by Cole, who passed away in 2006, he later played a significant role during the 2014 Ebola crisis in Sierra Leone. His efforts included educating over 10,000 people about the reality of Ebola, providing food and support to 11,000 individuals, and establishing an Ebola treatment unit with community help, saving many lives. Reflecting on his past atrocities, he now focuses on investing in young people to build a better future. The passage also notes the country was recently declared virus-free after nearly 4,000 deaths over 18 months, with total Ebola deaths in the region amounting to 11,314 across several countries.

Approximately 80,000 pieces of art, ceramics, manuscripts, letters, and photographs from the Wedgwood Museum in Barlaston, Staffordshire, were at risk of being auctioned to settle a pension debt inherited from the collapsed Waterford Wedgwood plc in 2009. A public fundraising campaign, initiated by The Art Fund in September, successfully met its target within a month, ensuring the collection remains on display at the museum. The Art Fund will gift the collection to the Victoria and Albert Museum, which will then loan it back to the Wedgwood Museum. This resolution followed complex negotiations and a 2011 high court ruling that permitted the sale of the collection to benefit the Pension Protection Fund. The outcome was celebrated by administrator Bob Young, local MP Tristram Hunt, and Alison Wedgwood, a descendant of the company founder Josiah Wedgwood, highlighting the collection's significance to Staffordshire and British cultural identity.

Dan Groves mentioned that the details of a deal allowing Mark Wright to buy 20% of Billericay Town Football Club are still undisclosed. According to The Sun, Wright, who was a runner-up on I'm A Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here in 2011 and played non-league football for clubs like Lewes and Crawley Town, will become a club director. Billericay, currently eighth in the Isthmian League Premier Division and three points from a play-off spot, was recently acquired by millionaire Glenn Tamplin. Tamplin is willing to invest £10,000 weekly in the club, which also recently signed former England international Paul Konchesky.

In a match between Blackpool and Colchester United that ended in a 1-1 draw, Blackpool took the lead early through Jamille Matt after a precise chip from Nathan Delfouneso. Colchester equalized shortly after with a goal from Kurtis Guthrie during a goalmouth scramble from a corner. Both teams had chances to win; Blackpool's Tom Aldred missed a close header, while Colchester's attempts were thwarted by Blackpool goalkeeper Sam Slocombe's brilliant saves. The game saw late drama as Colchester's Sean Murray was sent off with a straight red card for a bad tackle in injury time, leaving his team with 10 players. Multiple fouls, yellow cards, and substitutions marked the intense encounter.

The disused Fawley Power Station, located on the western side of Southampton Water, closed in 2013 after operating since 1971. The station, which powered one million homes, features a prominent 198-meter-high chimney. Fawley Waterside developers, who purchased the 300-acre site in 2016, plan to transform it into a "merchant city" with a £1bn development including a marina, housing, restaurants, and fast ferry links to Southampton and Portsmouth. The chimney, set to be the tallest attraction south of London's Shard, will be the centerpiece of this project, preserved as a signature piece of infrastructure. Outline planning permission is expected later this year, with construction potentially starting in 2018.

In the Hong Kong championships, 23-year-old Chris Latham secured Great Britain's second medal, a bronze, in the men's scratch race, finishing behind gold medalist Adrian Teklinski of Poland and silver medalist Lucass Liss of Germany. Latham expressed satisfaction with his performance, highlighting his strategic positioning and final sprint. However, GB's men's team pursuit team was outdone by Italy for the bronze. In other events, Joe Truman was eliminated in the men's keirin semi-final, and the GB women's team pursuit team finished fifth, missing the bronze-medal ride. Elinor Barker, part of the women's team and a previous silver medalist in the women's scratch, remained optimistic about the young team's potential for improvement. Additionally, Olympic bronze medalist Katy Marchant was knocked out in the first round of the women's sprint but is set to compete in upcoming events. Commentators including Chris Boardman and Sir Chris Hoy praised Latham's tactical race management and sprint finish.

Ross Kemp will briefly return to "EastEnders" as Grant Mitchell for the final episodes featuring Dame Barbara Windsor's character, Peggy Mitchell, who is set to die from cancer in emotional scenes this spring. Peggy, who last appeared in 2010, returned to inform her son Phil, played by Steve McFadden, of her cancer's return. Kemp, who portrayed Grant from 1990-1999 and in 2005-2006, expressed his desire to reunite the Mitchell family for this storyline, citing his close friendship with Barbara. Grant, a memorable character known for family dramas including affairs and complex relationships, will reunite with his brother Phil and past loves. Executive producer Dominic Treadwell-Collins highlighted the significance of the Mitchell brothers facing their mother's loss together, showcasing Kemp and McFadden at their best.

Sadio Mane scored two goals in quick succession as Tottenham Hotspur, currently in second place, underperformed at Anfield. Spurs' manager, Mauricio Pochettino, criticized his team's lack of desire and poor start, stating that such performances make it hard to compete for the Premier League title. He noted the potential 12-point lead Chelsea could gain over Spurs if they win their next match against Burnley. Spurs have struggled in away games against top-six teams, securing only one win in their last 17 such encounters. Pochettino and former player Danny Murphy highlighted tactical missteps and a lack of readiness to handle pressure, especially evident in their defensive setup and contrasting home and away performances.

The All Progressives Congress (APC) secured a significant victory in Nigeria's recent elections, winning 19 out of 28 governor posts, marking the largest defeat for the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP) since the end of military rule in 1999. This follows the APC's win in the presidential election, with leader Muhammadu Buhari set to be inaugurated on May 29 after defeating incumbent President Goodluck Jonathan. The PDP, which managed to retain only eight governorships mostly in the south-east, lost key northern states and failed to maintain a national spread, being relegated to a regional party. Notably, the APC did not win in any of Nigeria's five oil-producing states, posing potential challenges for Buhari concerning oil revenue and militancy. The elections, while more peaceful than in previous years, still saw violence, particularly in southern states like Rivers. Additionally, the APC retained control of Lagos, Nigeria's commercial hub, aligning it with the presidency for the first time since 1999. The PDP, after 16 years in power, faces the need for introspection and rebuilding amidst allegations of corruption and failure to address the Islamist insurgency in the north-east.

The Hebridean Celtic Festival, occurring from 19 to 22 July in Stornoway on the Isle of Lewis, introduces a new app featuring augmented reality. This app allows visitors to access online content like videos and band interviews by interacting with onsite signs and posters. Featured artists include The Waterboys, Imelda May, Lucy Spraggan, Skerryvore, Peatbog Faeries, and Dougie MacLean. According to festival director Caroline Maclennan, this technology enhances the festival experience for attendees and enables global interaction with the event, offering updates, ticket purchasing options, and a sense of the festival's unique atmosphere remotely.

Several Birmingham academies, including Park View, Nansen Primary, Oldknow Academy, and Golden Hillock School, have been rated inadequate by Ofsted amid concerns over a hardline Muslim takeover, known as the Trojan Horse plot. Funding agreements for Park View and Nansen Primary are set to be terminated, with the Park View Educational Trust potentially being removed from running these schools. Oldknow Academy and Golden Hillock School have been warned to address specific issues, such as discrimination and curriculum balance, by July 4, or risk losing funding. Education Minister Lord Nash expressed deep concerns about the management and cultural development at these schools. Ofsted reports highlighted a culture of fear and intimidation, inadequate safety measures against extremism, and improper vetting of external speakers. A head teacher from one of the schools described feeling isolated and undermined by parents during an inspection. Birmingham City Council and the Department for Education are intervening, including installing a temporary governing board at Saltley School, the only local authority school placed in special measures. Parents and school representatives have criticized Ofsted’s findings, alleging bias, while some staff express hope to improve ratings and focus on teaching.

Vincent Barker, known as Vinnie, passed away in July 2012, five months after a routine eye test at Boots in Ipswich. Honey Rose, a 35-year-old eye specialist, is charged with gross negligence manslaughter in Ipswich Crown Court for failing to detect Vinnie's swollen optic discs and refer him for further investigation. The prosecution claims this failure led to a fatal build-up of fluid in Vinnie's brain, increasing pressure in his skull. They argue that Vinnie's death was preventable and that Ms. Rose's conduct was so far below the expected standard of a competent optometrist that it was criminal. The trial is ongoing.

Clive Weatherhogg, 42, was found guilty at Dundee Sheriff Court of coercing a woman into sexual activities with a man he found online, filming these encounters, and sending explicit content to the victim's sister on Christmas Day 2014. The incidents occurred between September 2013 and September 2014. He was also convicted of causing the woman’s sister and father to view sexual images and behaving in a threatening or abusive manner. Despite denying the charges, Weatherhogg was placed on the sex offenders register. The case was remitted to the High Court in Edinburgh for sentencing due to its greater powers. Lady Wolffe emphasized the need for a sentence reflecting societal abhorrence, noting Weatherhogg as a first offender with a moderate risk of re-offending. His defense highlighted the shock of his remand ahead of sentencing.

In a T20 match in Greater Noida, Ireland scored 165-5, with Stuart Thompson scoring 56, Gary Wilson 41 not out, and captain William Porterfield 39. Despite their efforts, Afghanistan chased down the target, finishing at 171-4 with two overs remaining, led by Samiullah Shenwari's 56 and Mohammad Shahzad's 47. Afghanistan's victory was supported by an opening stand of 51 from Shahzad and Najeeb Tarakai. Ireland faced early setbacks with Paul Stirling dismissed for a duck and suffered further with the loss of paceman Boyd Rankin to a back injury for the T20 series, though he is expected to return for the ODIs starting March 15. Afghan spinner Amir Hamza took 2-23, the only bowler with multiple wickets. Porterfield noted that Ireland fell short of a potential 180 and struggled with their bowling execution. The teams are set to play again at the same venue on Friday.

The passage discusses the controversial transfer of Neymar to FC Barcelona from Santos for £48.6m, with his parents receiving £34m of the fee. The total cost to Barcelona, including various fees and wages over a five-year deal, amounts to £106.8m. Amidst allegations of financial misappropriation, former Barcelona president Sandro Rosell resigned and is under investigation, though he denies wrongdoing. A Spanish judge has found sufficient evidence to continue probing the transfer, despite Barcelona's denial of any tax-related crime. To address potential discrepancies in tax obligations and protect the club's reputation, Barcelona made an additional tax payment of over 13.5 million euros, while maintaining that their initial tax payment was correct. It remains unclear if the case will be dropped following this payment. Neymar has performed well, scoring seven goals in 18 league games and three in seven Champions League matches for Barcelona.

The bodies of David Miller, 24, and Hannah Witheridge, 23, were found on a beach in Koh Tao on September 15. UK Metropolitan Police officers collaborated with Thai police, who are holding two Burmese suspects, Zaw Lin and Win Zaw Htun, both 21-year-old migrant workers charged with conspiracy to murder, rape, and robbery. The suspects allegedly confessed, though there are reports they later retracted their confessions, which Thai police deny. UK detectives have completed their review in Thailand and will return to compile a report and update the victims' families. Post-mortem results indicate Miller died from drowning and a head blow, while Witheridge died from head wounds. DNA on Witheridge matched the suspects, according to Thai police. Concerns about the investigation, including DNA verification and suspect mistreatment, led the UK Foreign Office to summon the Thai charge d'affaires. The UK police visit was facilitated after a meeting between Thai Prime Minister Gen Prayuth Chan-ocha and UK officials, despite initial rejections of assistance.

The Scottish women's national football team, having won all five of their qualifiers, is set to host Iceland at Falkirk Stadium on Friday. A victory would nearly secure their spot in the finals. Ranked just below Iceland at world number 21, Scotland faces a strong opponent who is also unbeaten with four wins. The matches against Iceland, including a return fixture in Reykjavik on September 20, are crucial for determining the group leader. With the top six runners-up also qualifying automatically for next summer's finals in the Netherlands, Scotland is well-positioned to advance without a play-off. Forward Lisa Evans, a 24-year-old Bayern Munich player, expresses the team's determination to reach the finals, a goal shared by veteran goalkeeper Gemma Fay for 15 years. Evans highlights the tough competition from Iceland and the importance of fan support at Falkirk. She also notes the advantage of having 12 squad members, including herself, playing in top international leagues, which brings diverse skills and experiences to the national team. Evans recently celebrated winning the women's Bundesliga with Bayern Munich, an experience she describes as mind-blowing, further emphasizing the high level of competition and development in Germany’s league.

The passage discusses a security update by Apple to protect iCloud from unauthorized access following a breach where third-party software, specifically Elcomsoft's Phone Password Breaker, was used to steal celebrities' intimate photos. Apple has introduced a two-step verification process as an opt-in feature, which requires a four-digit code sent to a trusted device after entering a username and password on a new device. Failure to enter this code blocks access to iCloud and certain purchases. A 14-character recovery key is provided for account access if the trusted device is lost, though there are concerns about losing this key or it being stolen. Previously, even with two-step verification enabled, iCloud backups were vulnerable, but the new measures prevent such access, as confirmed by Elcomsoft's owner, Vladimir Katalov. Additional security includes email notifications for backup downloads. Despite these improvements, some experts, including Prof Alan Woodward from the University of Surrey, argue that two-factor authentication should be the default setting across tech companies like Apple, Microsoft, and Google. Apple plans to encourage users more actively to enable this feature and use stronger passwords, as stated by CEO Tim Cook.

In the May European election, UKIP emerged victorious, spending £2,956,737 on their campaign, which equates to 68p per vote for their 4,376,635 votes. The Conservatives spent slightly more at £2,980,815 (79p per vote), while Labour, coming in second, spent £1,027,339 (26p per vote). The Liberal Democrats spent £1,580,575 (£1.45 per vote) but lost 11 of their 12 MEPs. The Green Party, placing fourth, spent £534,249 (43p per vote) for their 1,255,573 votes. The SNP spent £267,372. Collectively, the six highest-spending parties spent £9,347,087 during the campaign period from January 23 to May 22, as reported by the Electoral Commission. All parties except Labour increased their spending compared to the 2009 European election.

Centre-back Anderson, aged 27, has mutually terminated his contract with Barrow to join a rival team in the National League, with a potential match against Barrow on February 18. Previously, he played for Aldershot, Exeter, and in Italy. Striker Keating, 21, joins the Gulls after a recommendation from ex-Port Vale manager Micky Adams, pending international clearance. Keating has experience with Sligo Rovers, Galway United, and Finn Harps. Gulls manager Kevin Nicholson describes Anderson as a leader despite limited game time for his age, and Keating as young, raw, but eager to prove himself. The Gulls are currently four points above the relegation zone, having won only one of their last six games.

A 10-year-old Irish-bred horse named Many Clouds collapsed and died after winning the Cotswold Chase at Cheltenham's Festival Trials Day, narrowly beating Thistlecrack. The British Horseracing Authority confirmed the cause of death as a severe pulmonary haemorrhage, a rare condition that can occur in horses without underlying health issues. Despite past episodes of post-race ataxia, where he overheated and wobbled, Many Clouds showed no such symptoms during this race and had never collapsed before. The horse, owned by Trevor Hemmings and trained by Oliver Sherwood, who called him the "horse of a lifetime," had previously won the Gold Cup trial in 2015 and the Hennessy Gold Cup in 2014. While questions have been raised about a possible link between his tendency to overheat and his death, the report concludes it was due to a rare haemorrhage. The racing community is committed to further understanding and preventing such incidents.

Presiding Officer Tricia Marwick was emotional as she bid farewell to retiring MSPs, including veteran Labour MSP Duncan McNeil and former First Minister Alex Salmond, ahead of the 5 May election. In his final speech, Salmond emphasized Scotland's diversity over division, highlighted the parliament's journey and increased strength, and welcomed new powers under the Scotland Bill, though he felt it fell short of referendum campaign promises. He also added humor by referencing competing events and wishing election candidates luck with varying enthusiasm. Duncan McNeil, in his farewell address, stressed the need for Holyrood to improve accountability and scrutiny, learning from Westminster's committee system. Former Conservative MSP Annabel Goldie also retired, humorously noting her interactions with Finance Secretary John Swinney. Marwick praised Salmond’s distinguished service to both parliament and Scotland.

The upcoming live-action film of "Beauty and the Beast," directed by Bill Condon, features a notable cast including Emma Watson as Belle, Dan Stevens as the Beast, Luke Evans as Gaston, Josh Gad as LeFou, Kevin Kline as Maurice, and a star playing Mrs. Potts, previously voiced by Angela Lansbury in the 1991 animated version. Filming starts in May at Shepperton Studios, with a release date set for March 17, 2017, in US cinemas.

The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is set to announce its decisions regarding potential charges against 23 suspects related to the 1989 Hillsborough stadium disaster, where 96 football fans were fatally injured, at a private meeting with victims' relatives at 11:00 BST in Warrington. The suspects are linked to two investigations: Operation Resolve, examining the causes of the disaster during an FA Cup semi-final, and an Independent Police Complaints Commission probe into police conduct post-disaster. Last year's inquests concluded the fans were unlawfully killed. Margaret Aspinall, a relative and chairwoman of the Hillsborough Family Support Group, expressed hope for closure while acknowledging the ongoing struggle and mixed emotions surrounding the CPS's decisions, emphasizing the families' determination for accountability.

Chelmsford Prison has reported multiple incidents of packages being thrown over its walls, contributing to a problem of contraband including mobile phones and synthetic cannabis flooding the facility, as noted by a former inmate. The Ministry of Justice acknowledges the hard work of staff to prevent such issues and states that the Justice Secretary is seeking solutions to better equip prisons against this challenge. A local resident has observed this activity frequently, and while not feeling threatened, takes precautions and notes the prison's initiative to discuss the issue with residents. Claims of drones delivering contraband directly to prison windows were dismissed by the Ministry of Justice due to lack of evidence at Chelmsford. Additionally, new laws allow for up to two years imprisonment for those caught smuggling packages over prison walls.

Sylvia Blackburn, a 72-year-old lollipop lady, suffered serious head injuries after being struck by a car driven by Brian Wright, 55, outside Bedford Road Lower School in Kempston last December. Wright, who claims he was blinded by the setting sun, hit Mrs. Blackburn while she was escorting a woman and child across the road at a red light. He denies causing serious injury by dangerous driving. Mrs. Blackburn is now in residential care. Wright expressed deep remorse in court, acknowledging the impact on Mrs. Blackburn and her family. The trial is ongoing at Luton Crown Court.

Laura Muir, a 24-year-old middle distance runner, will miss the Commonwealth Games on Australia's Gold Coast next year due to her veterinary medicine exams in May, which conflict with the event's April schedule. Despite her disappointment, Muir prioritizes completing her final year of university. She has previously placed fourth in the 1500m and sixth in the 5,000m at the World Athletics Championships, achieving a personal best of 14:52.07 in the 5,000m. Muir is considering the World Indoor Championships in March as a potential target and remains optimistic about her future, believing she has at least two or three more Olympics ahead. She expressed satisfaction with her recent performances despite the intense competition and frequent races.

Trevor Deely, a 22-year-old from County Kildare, disappeared in December 2000 after a Christmas party. A search operation began on a three-acre woodland site near the R112 and River Liffey in Chapelizod, Dublin, involving excavations expected to last several weeks. Earlier this year, a team of six detectives reviewed the case, enhancing CCTV footage from the night of his disappearance. The footage shows Deely speaking with an unidentified man in black outside the Bank of Ireland on Baggot Street, where Deely worked, and later being followed by presumably the same man on Haddington Road. Gardaí have appealed for this man to come forward, but he remains unidentified.

Juan Martin Del Potro, ranked 165th after a long injury hiatus, defeated Swiss player Stan Wawrinka 3-6, 6-3, 7-6 (7-2), 6-3 in a remarkable comeback at Wimbledon. The Argentine, a former US Open champion and world number four, returned to Grand Slam tennis after missing over two years due to wrist surgeries. Del Potro, who reached the Wimbledon semi-finals in 2013, expressed immense joy at his victory and the crowd's support, feeling revitalized in what he describes as his "second or third career." He is set to face either Lucas Pouille or Donald Young next and is in the same draw half as Andy Murray. Meanwhile, Australia's Nick Kyrgios overcame Dustin Brown in a rain-interrupted match, winning 6-7 (3-7), 6-1, 2-6, 6-4, 6-4, and will play Feliciano Lopez next, with a potential match against Murray in the last 16. Other notable wins included Tomas Berdych and Jo-Wilfried Tsonga advancing with straight-set victories.

Tunisia faced potential expulsion from the 2017 Africa Cup of Nations due to complaints against the Confederation of African Football (Caf) following a controversial penalty decision in a quarter-final match against Equatorial Guinea in the 2015 Nations Cup, which they lost 2-1. Tunisia's Football Federation (FTF) sent a critical letter to Caf, prompting a demand for an apology by March 31, 2015, to avoid disqualification. After a reconciliatory meeting with Caf president Issa Hayatou in Senegal, Tunisia resolved the issue and confirmed their participation in the 2017 qualifiers, where they are grouped with Togo, Liberia, and Djibouti in Group A.

Morocco, initially banned from the 2017 Nations Cup for refusing to host the 2015 tournament due to Ebola concerns, had their ban overturned by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas), and a fine reduced from $1m to $50,000. They were reinstated into the 2017 qualifying draw, placed in Group F with Cape Verde, Libya, and Sao Tome. Equatorial Guinea hosted the 2015 finals with only 64 days to prepare after Morocco's withdrawal.

The passage discusses the historical success and current challenges of the McLaren Formula 1 team. Once a dominant force with 182 Grand Prix wins, 12 drivers' world championships, and 8 constructors' titles, McLaren has experienced a significant decline, particularly since 2013 due to chassis design issues and current problems with the Honda power-unit. Despite having two world champions, including Fernando Alonso, the team now aims for modest grid positions and points. Historically, McLaren achieved great success with Honda in the late 1980s, winning 15 out of 16 races in 1988 with drivers Ayrton Senna and Alain Prost. The team faced scandals, such as the 2007 espionage issue with Ferrari data, resulting in a $100m fine and exclusion from the constructors' championship, and the 2009 'lie-gate' incident. Under Ron Dennis's leadership, who has been a pivotal figure since the 1980s, McLaren saw periods of domination but is currently struggling, though Dennis remains optimistic about breaking Mercedes' dominance and returning to championship success with improvements in car design and Honda's engine performance expected next year.

Paramedics were called to a sudden death at Joe's Bar in Dungiven at 06:00 BST on October 6, 2014, as reported in Limavady Magistrates Court. Police found people still at the bar upon arrival, with till receipts indicating alcohol sales as late as 04:49 BST. The judge ordered a three-month closure of the bar. Colleen O'Neill, 43, the license holder, was charged with two counts of allowing liquor consumption outside licensing hours and fined £3,000. James Thomas, 44, faced one count of the same charge and was fined £1,000. The defense admitted that licensing laws were not strictly followed, and the judge criticized the improper management of the premises and Ms. O'Neill's poor record, lamenting the inability to impose a custodial sentence.

Stephen Curry broke his own NBA record for the most 3-pointers in a season, scoring 45 points and hitting eight 3-pointers to lead the Golden State Warriors to a 116-105 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. Curry surpassed his previous record of 272 three-pointers, with assistance from Klay Thompson who scored 26 points, helping the Warriors overcome a 13-point deficit and avoid a three-game losing streak. For the Blazers, LaMarcus Aldridge scored 27 points with six rebounds, and Damian Lillard added 20 points and eight assists. In another game, Pau Gasol contributed 16 points and 15 rebounds as the Chicago Bulls overcame a 19-point halftime deficit to defeat the Miami Heat 89-78, significantly impacting Miami's playoff hopes. The Bulls, also led by Aaron Brooks and Taj Gibson with 14 points each, and Derrick Rose with 12 points, moved to the No. 3 spot in the Eastern Conference standings. Hassan Whiteside led the Heat with 19 points and 16 rebounds, while Dwyane Wade struggled, scoring only 9 points.

Liverpool players Mario Balotelli, Fabio Borini, Rickie Lambert, and Lazar Markovic were surprised during a training session at Melwood when they met Bas van Velzen, a YouTube star known for his free-kick skills. Initially presented as a competition winner, van Velzen soon revealed his exceptional talent in a dead-ball masterclass, impressing the players. The session included van Velzen and the players taking turns at free-kicks, with Balotelli also scoring a notable goal. Van Velzen expressed his excitement about meeting and playing with his idols, especially Balotelli, and enjoyed the surprise element of showcasing his skills. Additionally, van Velzen referenced Balotelli’s famous slogan from a past Manchester City game against United in 2011.

The passage discusses how women carrying the BRCA1 gene mutation, like Angelina Jolie, can significantly reduce their risk of death from breast cancer by undergoing an oophorectomy (ovary removal). A study of 676 breast cancer patients with BRCA mutations showed that oophorectomy led to a 62% reduction in breast cancer deaths among BRCA1 carriers, though not for BRCA2 carriers. The procedure also resulted in a 65% reduction in death from all causes and a 73% reduction in death for BRCA1 carriers who had the surgery within two years of diagnosis. The 20-year survival rate for the studied group was 77.4%. Additionally, women with BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations face a 50-80% lifetime risk of developing breast cancer. The study, published in JAMA Oncology, suggests that oophorectomy should be considered as part of treatment discussions for BRCA1 carriers with early-stage breast cancer, highlighting its survival benefits, particularly for those with estrogen-receptor negative breast cancer. Further research is recommended, especially for BRCA2 carriers and for those undergoing the procedure soon after diagnosis.

A married couple, Derek Lowe, 38, and Tina Lowe, 33, were struck and killed by an Amtrak train, Train No. 80 (the Carolinian), on Easter Sunday shortly before 10 am in Durham, North Carolina. The train was traveling from Charlotte to New York City on tracks owned by Norfolk-Southern. None of the 166 passengers on board were injured, though one passenger received treatment for an illness during the delay. The train was delayed for approximately two hours and 45 minutes before continuing its journey. Authorities reported that the couple may have been living in a homeless camp, as suggested by a man who knew them. Durham is about 25 miles northwest of Raleigh, the train's next stop, on a route that typically takes 13 hours and 30 minutes.

Carlos Toro, a 66-year-old former mid-level member of the Medellin Cartel, fled Colombia in the 1980s after a confrontation with his boss and began working as an undercover informant for the DEA in the United States. Over 27 years, Toro became one of the DEA's most valuable assets, aiding in significant prosecutions including those of cocaine overlord Carlos Lehder and ex-Panamanian dictator Manuel Noriega, and participating in undercover stings worldwide. Despite a promise of U.S. citizenship for his services, Toro, who was not paid for his work, faces deportation after retiring due to declining health. Now living illegally in the U.S., his temporary visa expired on January 1, and the DEA has refused to assist with his citizenship after he publicized his situation. Toro fears for his life if deported to Colombia, believing he would be killed within hours. He remains in limbo, unable to collect Social Security benefits without a green card or passport, and is prepared to go into hiding if necessary.

The US body regulating internet addresses, ICANN, is investigating a Canadian company, Vox Populi Registry Ltd., for potentially illegal practices involving the new '.sucks' domain name. This domain is being used to charge high fees, around $2,499 a year, to celebrities like Kevin Spacey and companies such as YouTube, Bing, Visa, Bank of America, and Yahoo, to protect their reputations by removing or preventing derogatory domain names. ICANN, which initially approved the '.sucks' domain among nearly 600 new top-level domains, is now reconsidering after complaints from an advisory panel of major companies and industry groups labeling it a 'shakedown scheme.' ICANN has reached out to US and Canadian authorities to assess the legality of Vox Populi's actions, which could lead to contract breach declarations and behavioral changes if found illegal. Meanwhile, Vox Populi plans to offer the domain to the general public for $10 a year starting in September, a move critics see as part of a coercive strategy.

A mother was arrested 27 years after her baby boy's body was found in a Sainsbury's bag floating in a pond in the village of Weasenham St Peter, Norfolk, on June 5, 1988. The case was reopened during a periodical review, and the boy's body was exhumed last year for DNA testing, which led police to his mother. The woman, unnamed, was initially arrested on suspicion of infanticide but explained that the baby was stillborn, and she had concealed the pregnancy and birth from family and friends. She admitted to placing the baby in the pond, known as Windmill Pit. After investigation, police ruled out foul play, and she remains on bail while the Crown Prosecution Service considers charges related to failing to register a birth and preventing a lawful burial. The baby, originally buried unnamed in 1988 with funds raised by villagers, was reburied on June 5 last year as Peter, named after St Peter’s Church, with a new headstone funded by a support group for stillborn children. Advances in DNA technology, comparing samples to a national database of five million, helped solve this long-standing mystery, though the exact cause of death remains undetermined after two post-mortems.

A taxi driver, Michael Young, 56, has been ordered to pay compensation to Kristopher Hicks, now 27, who suffered severe brain injuries after jumping out of Young's moving taxi in Bath, Somerset, five years ago. The incident occurred when Young, mistakenly believing Hicks intended to avoid paying the fare, drove him back to the taxi rank against his will. Hicks jumped from the vehicle traveling over 20mph, resulting in devastating injuries, epilepsy, and the need for constant care from his mother. High Court Judge Mr. Justice Edis ruled that Young had unlawfully imprisoned Hicks, entitling him to damages, though the compensation will be reduced by 50% and is expected to be in the hundreds of thousands of pounds. Hicks also received £250 for unlawful imprisonment. The exact compensation amount is pending a further hearing, and both parties can appeal the decision.

Tornado sirens sounded in Kansas on Wednesday night as multiple storms led to reports of twisters. A tornado was spotted near Goddard, close to Wichita, moving northeast and potentially threatening other areas. CNN expert Chad Myers warned of continuous storm activity through the night, emphasizing the danger of nighttime tornadoes. Additional tornado sightings were reported in southwestern Kansas near Aetna. Beyond Kansas, a possible tornado touched down in Potosi, Missouri, with reports of wind damage and flooding. Social media posts from the area showed fallen trees, damaged roofs, flooding, unusual cloud formations, and significant hail damage. More storms are forecasted for Thursday in the Midwest, Mississippi River Valley, Tennessee River Valley, and near the southern Great Lakes.

Luke Rockhold is set to face Lyoto Machida in a middleweight bout in New Jersey on Saturday, aiming for his fourth consecutive win since his loss to Vitor Belfort two years ago, with a title shot in view. Rockhold plans to dominate Machida by being aggressive and controlling the fight, likening himself to a bull against Machida's matador style. He believes he has identified weaknesses in Machida's approach and feels confident in his diverse skills as a mixed martial artist, asserting that Machida has limited chances of winning, especially on the ground. While Rockhold respects Machida's long-standing prowess and unique fighting style, he is determined to impose his own style and secure victory. Machida, coming off a recent win, is equally confident, believing that by applying his strategy and technique, he can defeat Rockhold and earn a title shot. Both fighters express readiness and mutual respect, with Machida highlighting his thorough preparation and Rockhold emphasizing his relentless training regimen.

In Fort Pierce, Florida, a light general aviation aircraft, an Aerostar, attempted to land at Aero Acres Residential Airpark without deploying its landing gear, resulting in a belly landing. The plane skidded along the runway, damaging its propellers and causing a significant impact sound as noted by a video maker at the scene. Realizing the error, the pilot, 85-year-old Chris Georgaklis, re-engaged the engines and managed a forced take-off despite the damage. Remarkably, he flew 100 miles to Fort Lauderdale and landed safely with his dog, Buddy, on board. Georgaklis has nearly 50 years of flying experience. The incident, captured on video, is under investigation by the FAA, with human error—forgetting to deploy the landing gear—cited as the most common cause of such gear-up landings, alongside potential mechanical failures.

Manuel Pellegrini, Manchester City's manager, expressed disappointment in midfielder Yaya Toure's performance this season, a sentiment Toure shares. Despite this, Pellegrini will support Toure until the season's end, although the club is open to offers for the Ivorian as part of a squad overhaul. Toure, who has two years left on his contract, has been criticized amid City's faltering Premier League defense. Pellegrini dismissed the idea of giving Toure a break and faces scrutiny over his own future. Manchester City, struggling with only 18 points from their last 39 available, will face West Ham without injured captain Vincent Kompany. Goalkeeper Joe Hart admitted the players have let Pellegrini down, despite the manager retaining the dressing room's support. Meanwhile, West Ham's Sam Allardyce cautioned his player Aaron Cresswell against moving to Manchester City, citing past examples of English players like Jack Rodwell and Scott Sinclair who had limited playtime there. Manchester City is interested in signing Cresswell to meet homegrown player quotas.

Domenico Rancadore, a Sicilian Mafia fugitive known as the "Godfather of Uxbridge," has been allowed to remain in the UK after his seven-year sentence for being a member of Cosa Nostra, handed down by an Italian court in 1999, was dropped. Having lived in Britain for over 20 years, Rancadore lost his extradition battle in February but it was later revealed that his case expired in October of the previous year under Italian law, which extinguishes a sentence after more than double the penalty time has passed. Consequently, the European Arrest Warrant against him is to be withdrawn. Although his conviction remains, the Italian Court of Appeal agreed to extinguish the sentence due to its age, and the case awaits final confirmation from the Italian Supreme Court. Rancadore, who fled to Britain in the 1990s and lived under the alias Marc Skinner, will continue to reside in the UK with his family, pending formal discharge of the proceedings at Westminster Magistrates' Court. Legal experts have criticized the significant time and resources spent on the case, especially since the sentence could no longer be legally enforced as of October of the previous year.

Mr Mole, ridden by AP McCoy, is one of three 7-2 co-favorites in the seven-runner Grade One Celebration Chase at Sandown on Saturday, alongside Special Tiara and Sprinter Sacre, the latter ridden by Nico de Boinville due to Barry Geraghty's injury. This race marks McCoy's last Grade One ride before retirement, which he announced after winning on Mr Mole at Newbury in February. McCoy's final rides as a professional jockey will be confirmed on Friday morning. Other competitors include Somersby, trained by Mick Channon.

Virginia Trimble Ritter's daughter, Marcia, was raped and murdered by Jerome Sydney Barrett in 1975. Marcia's body was discovered 33 days after her disappearance, hidden in a garage near her home. Initially, Ritter was advised by her then-husband not to view the body or crime scene photos, a decision she followed for decades. However, last year, she insisted on seeing the photos despite discouragement from the lead investigator, Mickey Miller. Upon viewing them, Ritter was overwhelmed by the horrific condition of her daughter's body and expressed a desire for revenge against Barrett. Barrett, who was also linked to another murder, was arrested in 2006 after DNA evidence connected him to Marcia's case. In 2009, he was convicted of second-degree murder and sentenced to 44 years in prison.

Rory McIlroy, the world number one golfer, is determined to win the Masters at Augusta National to complete his career Grand Slam, joining the elite group of only five other players who have achieved this feat. He considers winning the Masters a career-long goal and believes it is 'unthinkable' not to win at least one green jacket in his career, viewing the course as one where he could potentially win multiple times. McIlroy reflects on his significant collapse during the final round at Augusta in 2011 as the most important day of his career, which taught him valuable lessons about his game and mental resilience. Despite only one top-10 finish in six Masters appearances, he remains optimistic. Last year, despite personal and legal challenges, McIlroy found solace on the golf course, using it as a sanctuary from external pressures, and he anticipates a similar experience at Augusta amidst the hype and expectations.

This passage summarizes trending stories from a busy week. Key highlights include: four rainbows appearing in the New York sky after heavy rain, captured by Amanda Curtis; a crackdown on hiring exotic dancers at funerals in rural China; actor Robert Downey Jr. (RDJ) getting agitated during a Channel 4 interview about his personal life; the viral #kyliejennerchallenge involving lip plumping by sucking on a jar; a nostalgic moment for 102-year-old Alice Barker with filmmakers; a controversial prom-posal referencing bombs, leading to accusations of racism by the proposer; Ewan McGregor cast as Lumiere in 'Beauty and the Beast,' generating social media buzz; Johnny Depp appearing unrecognizable in the 'Black Mass' trailer; a creative pregnancy announcement referencing 'The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air'; and a military dad photobombing his son, noted for originality. All these stories trended during the week.

Last year, 272 children in England were hospitalized due to brain damage from foetal alcohol syndrome caused by exposure to alcohol in the womb, as reported by the Health and Social Care Information Centre. Experts suggest the actual number of affected children could be higher. The World Health Organization estimates that at least 1 in 100 babies born in the UK, roughly 7,500 annually, may experience learning, behavioral, and physical issues due to prenatal alcohol exposure. Elizabeth Mitchell from the National Organisation for Foetal Alcohol Syndrome highlighted the severity and under-diagnosis of the condition, noting that affected children do not recover. The case of 15-year-old Niamh Brown, diagnosed with the syndrome at age five, illustrates the lifelong challenges, including dependency and lack of danger awareness. Additional health issues linked to alcohol consumption during pregnancy include liver, kidney, and heart problems, cerebral palsy, sight loss, and epilepsy. While the government advises pregnant women to avoid alcohol, or limit intake to two units no more than twice a week, Mitchell advocates for a complete abstinence policy during pregnancy.

Shaun Andrew McKerry, a 31-year-old ex-juvenile offender known as "Boomerang Boy" or "Homing Pigeon Boy" for always returning home after crimes, attempted to rob Shildon Post Office and Stores in County Durham on March 15 at 8 pm. Masked and wielding an axe, he demanded cash but was tackled by the store owner, Sab Dhillon, and struck twice with a baseball bat by Dhillon's wife, Sam, which helped disarm him. Police arrested McKerry shortly after, and he was later jailed for six years following a guilty plea to attempted robbery at Durham Crown Court. McKerry has a long criminal history, starting shoplifting at age 12, with 80 arrests by age 15, and numerous convictions for various crimes.

Four Royal Navy sailors, Joshua Finbow (23), Craig Stoner (24), Simon Radford (31), and Darren Smalley (35), have been charged with the gang rape of a young woman in her early 20s at a party on April 10 at a Canadian naval barracks in Halifax, Nova Scotia. The incident occurred after a hockey game during a tournament at Shearwater Naval Base where they were representing the Royal Navy ice hockey team. They have been granted bail with conditions including a payment of over £2,000 each, surrendering their passports, and residing at Stadacona Naval Base in Halifax. They must remain in Nova Scotia, continue working for the Royal Navy, and are prohibited from contacting the victim and six witnesses. The sailors are charged with sexual assault causing bodily harm and group sexual assault, facing up to 14 years in prison. They are scheduled to return to court on May 27, and the investigation continues with potential for additional charges based on forensic results.

Valerie Jackson, a mother from Las Vegas, faces significant challenges due to her four-year-old son RJ's rare condition, Netherton's Syndrome, which affects only 70 people worldwide. This disease causes RJ's skin to appear red, inflamed, and scaly, resembling severe burns. Despite regular application of creams to manage his condition, Mrs. Jackson has encountered public misunderstanding and hostility, including being reported to the police for suspected child abuse while shopping. She and RJ also face cruel taunts and social exclusion, such as being denied entry to play centers. Netherton's Syndrome, a severe form of ichthyosis, has no cure and can lead to complications like infections and allergies, with symptoms potentially improving over time. Mrs. Jackson discovered the diagnosis through a supportive online group, highlighting the ignorance and stigma they endure, yet she remains devoted to her son, seeing beyond his condition to his inherent beauty and cheerful personality.

The passage discusses the controversy surrounding Protein World's "Are You Beach Body Ready?" advertising campaign on the London Underground, featuring a bikini-clad model, Renee Somerfield. The campaign sparked significant backlash from feminists and body image campaigners, leading to over 50,000 signatures on a Change.org petition and more than 200 complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority for promoting an unhealthy body image. Many posters were defaced, and social media saw thousands of critical tweets. Transport for London (TfL) confirmed the removal of the posters after the paid three-week advertising period ended, noting customer reactions for future similar campaigns. A protest against Protein World is planned for May 2 in Hyde Park. Protein World defended the unphotoshopped image and their campaign, despite receiving threats, including a bomb threat under police investigation. The company's head of global marketing, Richard Staveley, maintained the campaign's success and intent to continue similar advertising, while TV presenter Susanna Reid criticized it as "anxiety-inducing." Sales of protein powder in the UK are also noted to be increasing significantly.

Rail companies, particularly First Great Western (FGW), have faced criticism for planning significant fare increases of up to 87% shortly after the general election, despite promises from major party leaders to freeze or cap prices.
